ARTICLE V. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-258-2-277. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - JUVENILE HEARING BOARD[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Juvenile hearing board, G.L. 1956, § 16-19-8. 

Sec. 2-278. - Establishment. 
    Pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 16-19-8, a juvenile hearing board shall be established in the city for the purpose of hearing all cases referred to it by the juvenile division of the police department or the chief of police with respect to persons under the age of 18 who are charged with violating the criminal laws of the state or the city. Such board shall be called the "Central Falls Juvenile Board." 
(Code 1994, § 2-106; Ord. of 1-9-1995, § I) 
Sec. 2-279. - Membership. 
(a)  The membership of the city juvenile hearing board (the board) shall consist of not less than five nor more than seven residents of the city and one ex officio member named by the mayor from the city council over the age of 18 years. 
(b)  The members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council. 
(c)  The term of appointment for members of the board shall be for three years, except that the initial appointments shall be for less than three years, hereby staggering such initial appointments. 
(d)  Appointed members of the board shall be eligible for reappointment, and upon expiration of their term shall continue to serve until replaced or otherwise reappointed. In the event of a vacancy on the board, interim appointments of appointed members may be made by the mayor and confirmed by the council to complete the unexpired term of the vacant position. 
(Code 1994, § 2-107; Ord. of 1-9-1995, § II) 
Sec. 2-280. - Referral to the juvenile hearing board; exceptions; waiver of rights to family court. 
(a)  Persons who are under the age of 18 years may be referred to the board which shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the state family court if the alleged offense is one which, if committed by an adult, would be a misdemeanor. This requirement shall not apply in the case of any person: 
(1)  Charged with the offense of simple assault; 
(2)  Who shall have been twice previously referred to the board or have been once previously referred and refused or failed to abide by the sanctions imposed or make the restitution recommended; and 
(3)  Also at the time of the alleged commission of such offense shall be within the custody and control of the family court. 
(b)  The juvenile division of the police department or the chief of police may refer any other juvenile offender to the board where, in the opinion of the juvenile division or the chief of police, such referral would be beneficial to the juvenile concerned and the community at large. 
(c)  No referral to the board shall be made until such person, together with his legal guardians and/or legal representative shall have in writing waived such person's right to a hearing in the family court with respect to the offense charged, has admitted to the alleged offense and shall have agreed to abide by the decision of the board. 
(Code 1994, § 2-108; Ord. of 1-9-1995, § III) 
Sec. 2-281. - Duties. 
(a)  The board shall be authorized to hear all cases referred by the juvenile division of the police department or the chief of police, and to impose and order sanctions other than incarceration. Such sanctions may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Fines up to a maximum of $100.00 for each offense charged; 
(2)  Community service; 
(3)  Restitution for any injuries and/or damages, where appropriate, resulting from the commission of any offense; 
(4)  Imposition of a reasonable curfew; 
(5)  Denial or revocation of the juvenile's driving privileges for a period of up to two years. 
(b)  In any such proceedings, the board, prior to imposing sanctions, shall request the juvenile offender and his parents or legal guardians to agree to the sanctions imposed, the amount of restitution and manner of making the same. 
(c)  In ordering restitution, the board shall take into account the juvenile offenders' ability to pay and the amount of actual damage caused as a result of the commission of such offenses. 
(Code 1994, § 2-109; Ord. of 1-9-1995, § IV) 
Sec. 2-282. - Quorum; rules. 
(a)  A majority of the board's membership shall constitute a quorum, and a majority of the members present shall be required to take any action. Any juvenile offender may be represented by counsel and may present evidence in his behalf. 
(b)  The board shall have the power to, from time to time, adopt and publish all rules and regulations necessary to carry out its function under the provisions of this division. 
(c)  The board shall give notice of the date and time of meeting to the juvenile division of the police department or the chief of police, and the alleged juvenile offender and his parents or legal guardians, not less than seven days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(d)  Board proceedings shall be closed to the public, and the provisions of G.L. 1956, chapter 42-46 (G.L. 1956, § 42-46-1 et seq.) shall not apply to such proceedings. All records of proceedings, including records concerning the arrest, apprehension or detention of any juvenile offender, shall be withheld from public inspection, but such records shall be available to the parent, legal guardians or attorney of the juvenile for inspection. 
(Code 1994, § 2-110) 
Secs. 2-283-2-292. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - THE PAWTUCKET CENTRAL FALLS STATION DISTRICT JOINT PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-293. - Purpose. 
    There is hereby created the Pawtucket/Central Falls Station District Joint Planning Commission (hereafter known as the "JPC"), a joint planning commission created in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 45-22.1 by the cities of Central Falls and Pawtucket (hereafter known as the "cities"), that shall be responsible for: 
(1)  Planning for the revitalization of the Pawtucket Central Falls Station District (hereafter known as the "district") to ensure that the district will: realize its potential as a state-designated urban growth area; open up opportunities to reuse the historic mill buildings that are vacant or underutilized; stimulate the economic vitality of the area by strengthening and highlighting access to the multi-modal transportation options available, as well as to neighboring employment, social services, cultural and recreational activities; and, supporting both public and private infrastructure investments and development plans. 
(2)  Regulating development of the district in accordance with the powers granted to the commission by the ordinances and regulations of the cities of Pawtucket and Central Falls. 
(3)  When both cities have adopted an ordinance establishing the JPC, the chair of the Pawtucket Planning Commission shall call an organizational meeting of the JPC. Once this organizational meeting is held, the JPC shall notify both cities that it is operational. From that day forward, the JPC shall exercise the powers granted by this section. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-294. - Composition. 
    The commission shall consist of the members of the Pawtucket Planning Commission and the Central Falls Planning Board. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-295. - Election of officers, adoption of rules and staffing. 
(a)  The commission shall elect a chairperson, vice chairperson and a secretary whose terms do not exceed one year and who are eligible for reelection. The commission may create and fill any other offices that it may determine to be necessary. 
(b)  The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record is a public record. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-296. - Finances and staff. 
    The cities may appropriate funds for the purpose of contributing to the operation of the commission. The commission may receive grants from the federal or state governments, or from individuals or foundations, and may contract with these entities. Purchasing shall be in accordance with the requirements of the City of Pawtucket. 
(1)  The cities shall assign staff to the commission which shall assist the commission in its day-to-day activities. 
(2)  The commission may contract with planners and other consultants for the services it may require to the extent permitted by its financial resources. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-297. - Powers and duties of the commission. 
    The commission shall exercise the following powers in the district. 
(1)  Prepare and maintain a comprehensive plan for the district in accordance with the provisions of the cities' ordinances and G.L. 1956, § 45-22.2 for the guidance of the continuing development of the district. The commission may do planning work, including surveys, land use studies, urban renewal plans, technical services, and other elements of comprehensive planning and planning effectuation and said planning may be concerned with existing and proposed highways, public places, bridges and tunnels, viaducts, parks, parkways, recreation areas, sites for public buildings and structures, land use areas, building and zoning districts, waterways, routes of railroads and buses, location of sewers, water supplies and conduits, and other public utilities of the area. The plans shall be submitted to the cities for adoption as part of each city's comprehensive plan. 
(2)  Adopt, modify and amend regulations and rules governing land development and subdivision projects within the district and to control land development and subdivision projects pursuant to these regulations and rules. These regulations and amendments thereto, shall be adopted after a public hearing in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 45-23. 
(3)  Carry out development plan review as granted by the cities' zoning ordinances in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 45-24-49 and unified development review as granted by the cities' zoning ordinance in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 45-24-46.4. 
(4)  Recommend to the cities, for inclusion in the annual budget, a capital program of proposed capital projects for the five fiscal years next succeeding the budget year, the proposed projects to be arranged in order to preference with recommendations as to which projects should be constructed and in which year. 
(5)  Receive and review all applications in the district for variance and/or special use permit which are not part of a unified development review or change of zoning and make recommendations prior to the hearing on the application. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-298. - Cooperation with the commission-Municipalities and others. 
    The commission shall encourage the cooperation of the participating cities in matters which concern the integrity of the comprehensive plan or maps prepared by the commission, and, as an aid toward coordination, all municipalities and public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the commission within a reasonable time the available maps, plans, reports, statistical, or other information the commission may require for its work. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-299. - Pawtucket/Central Falls Station District. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Pawtucket/Central Falls Station District, a transit oriented development district. The purpose of this district is to create a community that includes a mixture of residential and commercial development and other amenities integrated into a walkable neighborhood and located within a half-mile of quality public transportation. This district is intended to create better access to jobs, housing and opportunity for people of all ages and incomes; to provide people from all walks of life with convenient, affordable and active lifestyles and create places where our children can play and our parents can grow old comfortably. 
(b)  The Central-Falls portion of the district is that area bounded as follows: 
Starting at the Pawtucket/Central Falls city line on Lonsdale Avenue and heading north along Lonsdale Avenue to a point that is halfway between Rand Street and Watson Street, then turning easterly and running along property lines to the intersection of Rand Street with Pine Street, then turning northwesterly and running along Pine Street to a point that is halfway between Mowrey Street and Richardson Street, then turning northeasterly and running along property lines to the intersection with Dexter Street, then turning southeasterly and running down Dexter Street to the intersection with Cross Street, then turning northeasterly and running down Cross Street approximately 400 feet, then turning southeasterly and running along the property lines until it intersects with Clay Street, then turn southwesterly and run down Cross Street until it intersects with Dexter Street, then southeasterly down Dexter Street to the Pawtucket/Central Falls city line. 
(c)  The Pawtucket portion of the district shall be designated by the City of Pawtucket. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Sec. 2-300. - Sunset. 
    Unless reauthorized by ordinance, this division shall sunset 20 years from the date of the organization meeting of the JPC. 
(Ord. of 5-8-2017(1) , § I) 
Secs. 2-301-2-312. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-313. - Acceptance of payment of delinquent taxes without recourse to assessment penalty. 
    The director of finance is hereby authorized and empowered to accept payment of delinquent taxes when, in his discretion, he believes the best interests of the city are being served without recourse to the assessment penalty. Any taxpayer, as a condition precedent to accepting the benefits of the provisions of this section, shall be deemed to have waived any and all protests, rights of protest and demands, either at law or in equity, which he may have by reason of the tax or assessment for which such abatements are herein granted to the taxpayer. 
(Code 1973, § 8-11; Code 1994, § 2-136) 
Sec. 2-314. - Settlement of claims against city. 
    The city council may make a settlement of any claim for damages against the city if such settlement seems to be advantageous to the interests of the city and if the claim appears to be a valid one. When a claim has been approved, the council shall certify the claim to the director of finance with the amount approved to be paid, and the director of finance shall forthwith pay such amount out of the contingent appropriation. 
(Code 1973, § 2-10; Code 1994, § 2-5) 
State Law reference- Actions by and against cities, G.L. 1956, §§ 45-15-1-45-15-15. 
Sec. 2-315. - Approval of compensation for wardens and ward clerks. 
    Before any bill for the compensation of any warden or ward clerk shall be audited for payment, the board of canvassers and registration shall approve the payment for each on a payroll voucher, but before such approval is made by the board of canvassers and registration, the wardens and clerks shall have returned to them their certificates as required by the public laws in relation to their duties. 
(Code 1973, § 8-3; Code 1994, § 2-128) 
Sec. 2-316. - Borrowing in anticipation of taxes. 
(a)  The director of finance shall notify the city council whenever a sum certain is required to be borrowed on the anticipated sums to be collected from taxes levied by the city during the fiscal year for the general operating budget of the city. The director of finance shall solicit bids or proposals for the sale of notes to be issued in anticipation of the collection of taxes by advertising at least one time in a newspaper having substantial circulation in the city. No bids shall be acted upon by the council until at least ten days have elapsed since such publication or at least seven days have elapsed since the last publication in the event that two or more publications of such advertisement have been ordered. All such bids shall be opened in a regular meeting of the council or in a special meeting of the council called for that purpose. 
(b)  The finance director shall keep a list of banks normally interested in submitting bids for the purchase of tax anticipation notes and shall request bids from at least two-thirds of the banks on such list. All such bids received by the director of finance shall be turned over by him to the clerk of the council to be opened in a regular meeting of the council or in a special meeting of the council called for that purpose. 
(c)  It shall be the established policy of the council to award the sale of all tax anticipation notes to the lowest responsible bidder, except where the director of finance makes known to the council reasons that shall warrant the rejection of such bid. After hearing the finance director, the council shall accept the lowest bid or the bid in accordance with the recommendation of the director of finance or a bid in accordance with the recommendation of a special committee appointed by the council for the purposes of investigating the proposed bids, or it shall reject all bids and order the obtaining of new bids. The accepting of any such bid shall be by resolution passed in accordance with the provisions of the Charter for the city. 
(Code 1973, § 8-4; Code 1994, § 2-129) 
Sec. 2-317. - Accounts of matured indebtedness to city to be filed with director of finance. 
    It shall be the duty of the officer having charge of any department of the city government in which any indebtedness to the city shall accrue, not later than one month thereafter, to make out and file with the director of finance accounts thereof, with notices that such accounts are due and payable to the director of finance. 
(Code 1973, § 8-6; Code 1994, § 2-131) 
Sec. 2-318. - Monthly report; payment of money and fees received by officers. 
    All officers now by law authorized to receive fees or money and by law required to make returns of such fees or money under oath shall, on or before the third day of each month, make a detailed return, under oath, to the director of finance of all fees and moneys received by them during the preceding month and shall pay over such money to the director of finance as required by law. 
(Code 1973, § 8-7; Code 1994, § 2-132) 
Sec. 2-319. - Annual statement of money due city from departments. 
    Each department of the city government shall render to the director of finance on July 1 in each year a detailed statement of all moneys due therefrom to the city for the preceding fiscal year that have not been previously reported to the director of finance. 
(Code 1973, § 8-8; Code 1994, § 2-133) 
Sec. 2-320. - Schedule of real estate and leases; summary of inventories. 
    The accounting division shall annually, on or before the first Monday in July, prepare a schedule of all real estate of the city and the leases thereof with the names of the lessees, the rate of rent and the time when such leases respectively terminate. In addition, they shall prepare a summary of the inventories mentioned in this article, giving the valuation of all the personal property belonging to the city which may be in the custody of any officer or agent of the city, together with the names of the persons having charge of such property, and for this purpose every officer of the city or other person in whose control or custody any such property may be is hereby required to present to the accounting division, on or before June 15 in each year, a detailed inventory of all such property, giving the items and the valuation thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 8-9; Code 1994, § 2-134) 
Sec. 2-321. - Employment of tax collection attorneys. 
    The finance director and the city solicitor are hereby authorized and directed to employ attorneys at law to aid in the collection of personal property taxes due and payable to the city. The terms and conditions of employment, including compensation, shall be determined by the finance director. The city council shall appropriate such sum of money as may be deemed necessary to pay for such services and for all other expenses to be reasonably incurred in connection therewith. Payment shall be made upon vouchers duly approved by the finance director. 
(Code 1973, § 8-10; Code 1994, § 2-135) 
Sec. 2-322. - Register of city debts. 
    The director of finance shall cause to be prepared a register of the number, date, amount, day of payment and rate of interest of every city note, bond or other obligation outstanding. Whenever any note, bond or other obligation of the city shall be issued, the director of finance shall record in such register all the particulars stated in this section, and whenever any city note, bond or other obligation shall be paid or cancelled, the director shall record in his records the fact that such payment or cancellation has been made. Such register of the city debts shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1973, § 8-17; Code 1994, § 2-139) 
Sec. 2-323. - Departments to submit annual report of stock on hand. 
    All city departments shall submit to the purchasing agent on or before July 31 in each year a report showing stocks of supplies, materials and equipment on hand awaiting use. 
(Code 1973, § 8-32; Code 1994, § 2-140) 
Sec. 2-324. - Disposition of surplus or obsolete stocks. 
    When a surplus of stock exists in one department, the purchasing agent may transfer it to any other department having need for it. Any sale of supplies, materials and equipment not needed for public use or that may have become unsuitable for public use shall be based on competitive bids. 
(Code 1973, § 8-33; Code 1994, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-325. - Reports by purchasing agent. 
    The purchasing agent shall submit to the city council such reports from time to time as may be requested by them concerning his work. 
(Code 1973, § 8-34; Code 1994, § 2-142) 
Sec. 2-326. - Disaster response expenses; exceptions. 
(a)  Any private facility operating within the city that houses any convicted prisoners of this or any other state must post with the city clerk a true and certified copy of a financial bond or insurance policy issued by a recognized and sound financial institution or insurer and naming the city as beneficiary or coinsured in an amount not less than $100,000.00 times the maximum inmate capacity of the facility, to provide the city, that is self-insured with respect to its police and fire disability payments and pensions, with adequate security for its reasonably foreseeable expenses of responding to a disaster at such facility. 
(b)  The city council shall request the opinion of the attorney general of the state if any question arises as to the soundness of any financial institution or insurer and the opinion of the attorney general in such respect shall be deemed conclusive. 
(c)  The claims allowable by the city council on behalf of the city or any of its citizens against such bond or insurance policy shall include, but are not limited to, claims for personal injury, disability, loss of income, loss of life or the enjoyment of life, property damage, business interruption and all the direct and indirect costs incurred by the city in responding to any disturbance at such a facility. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any facility within the city exclusively housing federal detainees awaiting trial. 
(Code 1994, § 2-143; Ord. of 3-15-1994, §§ 10-21-1-10-21-4) 
Sec. 2-327. - Operating budget balance sheet due. 
    The accounting division shall submit to the city council on a monthly basis a detailed line item departmental balance sheet of the city's current year operating budget. 
(Code 1994, § 2-145; Ord. of 10-23-2000) 
Sec. 2-328. - Reserve fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created a reserve fund which must maintain a minimum fund balance of ten percent of the previous fiscal year's expenditures. 
(b)  The mayor may request of the city council the appropriation of any amount available within the fund for emergency purposes and the city council may only grant approval of the appropriation request with the affirmative vote of five members of the council. 
(c)  The finance director shall make a monthly accounting to the city council on the status of the fund. 
(Code 1994, § 2-146; Ord. of 6-8-2001; Ord. of 6-13-2001; Ord. of 6-19-2017(1) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Reserve funds authorized, G.L. 1956, § 45-11-1. 
Sec. 2-329. - Reappropriation of capital program and capital budget. 
(a)  The city council must, by ordinance, reauthorize and reappropriate the use of any dollar amounts remaining in the capital program and capital budget ordinances, by a majority vote of the city council, if not properly already so authorized and encumbered before June 30, 2001. 
(b)  The mayor and the finance director may annually request the city council to reappropriate any remaining funds available within these programs until June 30, next. 
(c)  The mayor shall report quarterly to the city council on all changes and authorizations of these funds and within 30 days of all special requests made by the city council. 
(d)  The finance director shall make a monthly accounting to the city council on the status of these funds. 
(Code 1994, § 2-147; Ord. of 8-20-2001) 
Sec. 2-330. - Capital improvement fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created a capital improvement fund in accordance with section 2-304 of the Home Rule Charter of at least $250,000.00. 
(b)  This fund shall be used to make capital improvements, to acquire and maintain all types of equipment, to purchase property and for all physical improvements in the city. 
(c)  The finance director shall make a monthly accounting to the city council on the status of the fund. 
(Code 1994, § 16-1; Ord. of 5-31-1995(2), §§ 1-4; Ord. of 6-19-2017(1) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Reserve funds authorized, G.L. 1956, § 45-11-1. 
Sec. 2-331. - Schedule of fees for licenses and permits. 
    The comprehensive schedule of fees for licenses and permits required by this Code is not printed in this volume but is on file and available in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1973, § 14-1; Code 1994, § 12-8; Ord. of 4-9-1990(1); Ord. of 11-12-1991(1); Ord. of 8-26-2002; Ord. of 8-24-2009) 
Sec. 2-332. - The economic expansion incentive program. 
(a)  Job creation incentive plan. Any business operating within city limits that, upon enactment of this section-economic expansion incentive program-creates and/or adds a minimum of five new permanent full-time or full-time equivalent jobs will be eligible for tax exemptions percentages for additional tangible personal property located at the business situs within the city limits under the following schedule: 
Year 1 - 5-9 Jobs = 50% 
Year 1 - 10-49 Jobs = 60% 
Year 1 - 50+ Jobs = 70% 
  
Year 2 - 5-9 Jobs = 40% 
Year 2 - 10-49 Jobs = 50% 
Year 2 - 50+ Jobs = 60% 
  
Year 3 - 5-9 Jobs = 30% 
Year 3 - 10-49 Jobs = 40% 
Year 3 - 50+ Jobs = 50% 
  
Year 4 - 5-9 Jobs = 20% 
Year 4 - 10-49 Jobs = 30% 
Year 4 - 50+ Jobs = 40% 
  
Year 5 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 5 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 5 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
  
Year 6 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 6 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 6 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
  
Year 7 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 7 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 7 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
  
Year 8 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 8 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 8 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
  
Year 9 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 9 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 9 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
  
Year 10 - 5-9 Jobs = 10% 
Year 10 - 10-49 Jobs = 20% 
Year 10 - 50+ Jobs = 30% 
(1)  Employers who fill at least 20 percent of newly created jobs with city residents will receive an additional five percent personal tangible property tax exemption for additional tangible personal property. 
(2)  Employers who provide employees with a group medical insurance plan will receive an additional five percent personal tangible property tax exemption on additional tangible personal property. 
(3)  Employers who pay annual salaries or wages to at least 20 percent of the newly created jobs rates of 250 percent of the minimum annual wage (currently $38,480.00) or more will receive an additional five percent tax exemption on additional tangible personal property. 
(b)  Real property improvement plan. Any property owner renovating or upgrading any property within the city where such renovations or upgrades, approved by the building inspector, result in an increase in the assessed value of the structure, as determined by the tax assessor, shall be eligible for tax exemption percentages on the increased amount over a 12-year period under the following schedule: 
Year 1 - 100% 
Year 2 - 75% 
Year 3 - 50% 
Year 4 - 50% 
Year 5 - 50% 
Year 6 - 50% 
Year 7 - 25% 
Year 8 - 25% 
Year 9 - 25% 
Year 10 - 25% 
Year 11 - 10% 
Year 12 - 10% 
(1)  In order to be eligible for the above-referenced real property tax exemption percentages the following criteria shall be applicable: 
a.  Qualifying property owner must invest in the new construction or substantial renovation of an existing structure on his or her property. 
b.  Qualifying vacant or abandoned properties are eligible for a separate, additional five percent exemption in addition to the above referenced exemption percentage for the duration of the exemption period. 
c.  Qualifying historic properties are eligible for a separate additional five percent exemption in addition to the above referenced exemption percentage for the duration of the exemption period. 
d.  Investments that would result in an increased assessed value of over $5,000,000.00 will receive a separate, additional five percent exemption in addition to the above referenced exemption percentage for the duration of the exemption period. 
e.  Investments that would result in an increased assessed value of over $10,000,000.00 will receive a separate, additional five percent exemption in addition to the above referenced exemption percentage for the duration of the exemption period. 
f.  Property owners must invest a minimum of $50,000.00 in cumulative building permits to qualify for the phase-in schedule. 
(c)  Development fees waiver. Any property owner who receives the approvals pursuant to subsection (d) for the tax benefits of subsection (a) or (b) may petition the planning director and the finance director for their joint approval of a waiver of some or all building, fire, zoning and planning permit and review fees, as allowed by law. 
(d)  Approval required. All of the tax incentives in this section are subject to the discretion and approval of both the finance director and the planning director. The director of planning shall promulgate and publish rules and regulations, including, but not limited to, an application procedure, within 30 days of passage of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(Ord. of 11-28-2016(1) , § 1; Ord. of 6-12-2017(1) , § 1) 
Secs. 2-333-2-348. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-349. - Cooperative purchasing.

Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]

DIVISION 2. - RETAIL LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Retail licenses, G.L. 1956, § 3-7-1 et seq. 

Sec. 4-40. - Maximum number of licenses fixed. 
(a)  The maximum number of class A, class B, class C, class D (limited), class D (full privilege) and class T (legitimate theater) alcoholic beverage licenses which may at any time be issued and outstanding within the city is hereby fixed as follows: 
Class of License Maximum Number A 4 B (victualler) 25 B (limited) 8 C 0 D (limited) 0 D (full privilege) 2 T (legitimate theater) 0 B-M (brewpub manufacturer) 1 *  
(b)  The specific project identified as 1420 Broad Street, "The Landing," has a site and project specific B-M license and class B (victualler) license, subject to suspension or revocation by the city council, sitting as the city board of license commissioners, for violations of Title 3 of the Rhode Island General Law and/or relevant city ordinances. 
(c)  Effective upon passage of this ordinance, the total number of class B (victualler) liquor licenses shall be diminished by that number that have failed to renew or have been revoked until the 25 current and active class B (victualler) licenses reach a quantity of 22 B (victualler) licenses. 
(d)  All holders of class D (full privilege) licenses may apply for class B (victualler) licenses, and the city council, sitting as the board of license commissioners, may grant such applicant a class B (victualler) license and thereby increase the number of such licenses; provided, however, that the number of class B (victualler) licenses shall never exceed 27 in number, the number of outstanding class D (full privilege) licenses shall be reduced by the number of such class B licenses so issued, that such class B (victualler) license shall remain in effect only as long as the original class D license holder remains the same entity as originally established, and that the newly issued class B (victualler) license shall be nontransferable. 
(e)  Upon an aforementioned license becoming available, the city, in its discretion, may advertise and accept applications for the new license in the following manner: 
(1)  The clerk shall advertise the application for the available license(s) on the city's website and on relevant city bulletin boards for a minimum of 14 days. The application shall be developed by the clerk and shall include, but not be limited to, a BCI check, a 200 foot radius map, mailing labels for all of those within the 200 foot radius, a certified check and/or money order for the costs of mailing to those within the 200 foot radius, and a business plan for the proposed establishment including answers to the following questions: 
a.  Will the business promote the general economic development of the city; and 
b.  Is the proposed location one that is targeted for commercial development; and 
c.  Will the business promote revitalization of the area where it will be located; and 
d.  Will the issuance result in substantial employment opportunities; and 
e.  Is the business proposed one that presents a unique concept not currently existing in the city. 
f.  What is the law enforcement track record of the applicant(s) or the establishment and the applicant's plan relating to security and the prevention of underage drinking and/or drinking in excess. 
(2)  The city council, sitting as the city board of license commissioners, shall conduct a public hearing on each application and, thereafter, shall consider a list of eligible applications for the lottery. The city council has general discretionary authority to deny a license application's eligibility for the lottery based on the following criteria: 
a.  Objection is made by owners of the greater part of the area within 200 feet of the premises where a Class B, C or I license is to be operated. (Rhode Island General Laws § 3-7-19) If the owner or owners of the majority of this area object, then the Council is without authority to issue the license. The area within 200 feet of the premises means the area within a line 200 feet distant from every side of the proposed premises. 
b.  Premises is located within 200 feet of a school or place of public worship. (Rhode Island General Laws § 3-7-19) The 200 foot measurement shall be made from that point of the proposed licensed place closest to the nearest improved point of the school or place of worship. 
c.  Compliance with all city ordinances. 
d.  The history of operations at the premises for which a license is requested. 
e.  Qualification of the applicant to hold and operate the license. 
f.  Failure of applicant to comply with the requirements of state law, including, but not limited to: 
1.  Applicant must be a resident of Rhode Island, except that licenses may be issued to corporations incorporated in other states of the United States if they are authorized to transact business in Rhode Island. (R.I.G.L. § 3-5-10) 
2.  Corporate applicants with 25 stockholders or less must provide a list of the names and addresses of all stockholders, officers and members of the board of directors to the city council, and each person listed must be a suitable person to hold a license within the discretion of the city council. (R.I.G.L. § 3-5-10) 
3.  Failure of a corporation to report the acquisition of a ten percent interest and any change of officer or directors within 30 days. (R.I.G.L. § 3-5-10) 
4.  Applicant has a criminal record or repeated violations of the alcoholic beverage laws. (R.I.G.L. § 3-5-10) 
(3)  Each application that has been deemed eligible for the lottery shall be given one ball to put into the lottery. Each applicant may receive an additional one or two chances to be put into the lottery for his or her application if they meet the following criteria, as determined by the city council: 
a.  Is the applicant currently a resident of the City of Central Falls? 
b.  Is the applicant currently a business owner in good standing with the City of Central Falls? 
(f)  No application or petition for granting, renewing or transferring a license may be approved by the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners if the existing license holder, applicant or petitioner is delinquent in the payment of taxes to the city for the real property where the business is situated or for personal property and/or tangible property utilized in the operation of the business. 
(Code 1973, § 3-4; Code 1994, § 4-4; Ord. of 5-11-1992; Ord. of 8-16-1993(3), § 1; Ord. of 12-11-1995; Ord. of 3-18-1998(1); Ord. of 6-8-1998; Ord. of 4-14-2003; Ord. of 6-1-2005(2); Ord. of 8-13-2014; Ord. of 12-14-2015 , §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license the sale of alcoholic beverages, G.L. 1956, § 3-5-15; retail licenses, G.L. 1956, § 3-7-1 et seq.; maximum number of licenses, G.L. 1956, § 3-5-16. 
Sec. 4-41. - Licenses void. 
(a)  All licenses issued under this chapter must be paid for and claimed from the city clerk within 30 days following the approval of the license by the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners. All licenses not claimed within such 30 days shall be automatically null and void; provided, that if a reasonable cause for failure to claim such license shall be filed with the city clerk within 30 days of the approval of such license, the city council, sitting as the city board of license commissioners, may, if it finds the cause adequate, grant a further extension within which such license may be claimed. 
(b)  Whenever it is determined by the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners that the holder of any liquor license issued on an annual basis has abandoned the premises from which the licensee has been conducting business or shall have ceased to operate under the license for a period of not less than 90 days, the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners shall hold a hearing after giving written notice to the licensee and may declare the license void, vacated and/or revoked, provided that the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners may grant a reasonable time, not to exceed nine months, to the licensee within which to reestablish his or her interest in the business where the abandonment or cessation of operations shall have been due to illness, death, fire or other casualty, condemnation of business or other good cause. 
(Code 1973, § 3-5; Code 1994, § 4-5; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
Sec. 4-42. - Transfer of license. 
(a)  All licenses issued under this chapter granted and issued by the city after the effective date of this ordinance shall not be transferred to a new license premises or to another person, without application to and approval of the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners which shall use the factors enumerated in section 4-40(e)(2) in consideration of the application. 
(b)  No liquor license holder shall make or allow to be made substantial changes to the operation of his/her establishment from that which is represented at the issuance of the license, without first obtaining the approval of the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners which shall use the factors enumerated in section 4-40(e)(2) in consideration of the application. 
(c)  A transfer of a license shall not be issued by the city clerk unless all requirements in this chapter have been met, the currently required fee is paid, and the applicant is not delinquent on any taxes to the city for the real property where the business is situated or for personal property and/or tangible property utilized in the operation of the business. 
(Code 1973, § 3-6; Code 1994, § 4-6; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
State Law reference- Transfer or relocation of licenses, G.L. 1956, § 3-5-19. 
Sec. 4-43. - City liquor establishments. 
(a)  Management and personnel. All personnel managing, working in or in charge of any establishment holding or seeking a license to permit the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages must meet the same requirements in the city as the licensee must meet to be a licensee under state or city law. Violators of this section will be referred to the proper state agency for prosecution under the state statutes for violation of local rules, regulations or laws. 
(b)  Regulation of trade names. All licensees, with their application submitted to the state liquor license commission, will also submit for approval the name which the establishment will be called. Any name, except the legal name of the licensee if an individual, can be rejected by the commission if within its discretion it may find the name by its tone or double meaning to be disruptive to the community. 
(Code 1973, §§ 3-7, 3-8; Code 1994, § 4-8; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
Sec. 4-44. - License fees. 
(a)  The applicant shall be responsible to pay all advertising and related costs for transfer or new alcoholic beverage licenses. 
(b)  The annual license fee for a class B license shall be $2,000.00 notwithstanding if said fee is paid on or before December 1, then the license fee for a class B license shall be $1,500.00. 
(c)  The annual license fee for a class A license shall be $1,000.00 notwithstanding if said fee is paid on or before December 1, then the license fee for a class A license shall be $800.00. 
(d)  The annual license fee for a class B Ltd license shall be $1,500.00 notwithstanding if said fee is paid on or before December 1, then the license fee for a class B Ltd license shall be $1,300.00. 
(e)  The annual license fee for a class D license shall be $800.00 notwithstanding if said fee is paid on or before December 1, then the license fee for a class D license shall be $600.00. 
(f)  The fee for a class F license shall be $15.00 for each application and the fee for a class F1 license shall be $35.00 for each application. 
(Code 1994, § 4-9; Ord. of 12-14-2003; Ord. of 6-26-2006; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
Sec. 4-45. - Class F and F1 licenses. 
(a)  The city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners may grant a class F, for sale of beer and wine only, or class F1 license, for sale of beer, wine and liquor, to an applicant provided that the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  Only the beer, wine and liquor as described in the license application may be sold on premise; and 
(2)  The license is only valid for a maximum of 19 hours; and 
(3)  The license is only valid between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m.; and 
(4)  The only eligible applicants for this license are religious organizations, non-profit organizations and political organizations; and 
(5)  The license is to be considered a "special event" license, which is not subject to issuance on a regular basis to the same party and/or premises. "Special Event" is defined as any occasion and/or event which shall occur at irregular intervals of time not subject to any permanent scheduling. No licensee may receive more than five such licenses in any one calendar year. Upon a showing of good cause, the City Council sitting as the city board of license commissioners may grant up to an additional seven licenses to a proposed licensee whose event exceeds said five licenses; and 
(6)  The applicant must present evidence that all bartenders employed by the licensee shall be certified by a Nationally Recognized Alcohol Beverage Server Training Program. 
(7)  The applicant shall purchase all alcoholic beverages at retail from a licensed class A alcohol retail establishment located in the State of Rhode Island. 
(8)  The city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners has weighed and considered the following facts and evidence: 
a.  Whether proper health and safety precautions have been put into place; 
b.  Adequate police control or protection; 
c.  Satisfactory sanitary and health facilities on the premises. 
d.  Control procedures that will be in place to prevent under-aged drinking and excessive drinking by any individual or individuals frequenting the "special event." 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall be enforced in accordance with Title 3 of the General Laws. Any person or entity violating this section shall be fined $500.00 for such violation and shall be subject to license suspension and/or revocation. 
(Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
Secs. 4-46-4-61. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENTERTAINMENT IN PREMISES LICENSED FOR ON-PREMISES CONSUMPTION 

Sec. 4-62. - Liquor license suspension, revocation or other sanction. 
(a)  The city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners may summon any licensee on charges and/or for a hearing on charges of violating any city, state or federal regulation or law. After notice and the opportunity to be heard, the city council sitting as the city board of license commissioners may sanction the licensee including fines, suspension of license, revocation of license, and/or any other sanction reasonably related to the findings of fact. 
(b)  If the owner, operator, licensee, lessor, lessee, manager, employee, or any other person participating in the operation of the establishment located within the city at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, shall violate or be in violation of any of the provisions of section 4-63, the city council shall revoke the liquor license for said establishment after giving reasonable notice thereof to the holder of said license and affording the holder an opportunity to be heard as to why the license should not be revoked. 
(Code 1994, § 6-187; Ord. of 11-6-2000; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
Sec. 4-63. - Prohibition. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment located within the boundaries of the city at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of said establishment, to expose to the public view that area of the human female breast at or below the top of the areola thereof. 
(2)  To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of said establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such portions of the human female breast as described in subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(3)  To suffer or permit any person, while on the premises of said establishment, to expose to public view his genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft. 
(4)  To suffer or permit any person, while on the premises of said commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any female person, while on the premises of an establishment located within the city, at which alcoholic beverages are served or offered for sale for consumption on the premises to expose to public view that area of the human female breast at or below the top of the areola thereof, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance or simulate such areas of the female breast as described herein. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of an establishment located within the city, at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, to expose to public view his genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft. 
(Code 1994, § 6-185; Ord. of 11-6-2000; Ord. of 8-13-2014) 
State Law reference- Indecent exposure, G.L. 1956, § 11-45-1(a)(8). 
Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GAMES OF CHANCE[2]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-19. - Definitions.

Secs. 6-20-6-41. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-42. - Issuance. 
    All permitted game of chance licenses shall be issued by the city clerk upon granting of such license by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 14-78; Code 1994, § 6-64) 
Sec. 6-43. - Fee. 
    There shall be no fee for a license carrying on or conducting a permitted game of chance. 
(Code 1973, § 14-77; Code 1994, § 6-65; Ord. of 6-4-2001)

ARTICLE III. - ENTERTAINMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Shows and exhibitions, G.L. 1956, § 5-22-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-75. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Entertainment means any live production of music or sound by an individual, band, musician, any theatrical performance, show or exhibition or performance, including, but not limited to, karaoke, public roller skating in rinks or halls, dances and balls, wrestling, boxing or sparring matches, exhibition, activities of a palmist, phrenologist or fortuneteller or any other entertainment and amusements for a term not exceeding one year. Any music or sound provided by any mechanical, electronic or other means, such as a tape recorder, records or other audio or visual means. 
    Individual business or establishment means any person, corporation, limited liability company, club, partnership, association, society or any other organized group of persons, including officers, directors and trustees of a corporation, club, association or society. 
    Premises means any room, place or space in the city in which entertainment, as defined herein, is produced or provided to which the public may gain admission, either with or without the payment of a fee, including, but not limited to, any building, theater, hall or rink. 
(Code 1994, § 6-37; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-76. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of the city council in this article to adopt a specific distinguishable license for the operation of entertainment, as defined herein, as allowed by the laws of the state. It is the further purpose of this article to address the secondary effects of entertainment establishments and businesses that are referenced and defined herein. Secondary effects have been shown to include increased crime, which has adverse impacts on the quality of life in the community. All mentioned secondary effect impacts are adverse to the public health, safety, and general welfare of the city and its residents. 
(Code 1994, § 6-36; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-77. - Hours and posting of license. 
(a)  All individual or business establishments providing entertainment as defined herein, shall discontinue entertainment and be closed on or before 1:00 a.m. If said individual or business establishment does not have a liquor license, then the closing time will be set by the city council at the time the application is acted upon but shall not be later than 1:00 a.m. 
(b)  Each license issued hereunder shall be displayed in a conspicuous place at such location. 
(Code 1994, § 6-45; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Secs. 6-78-6-97. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-98. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual or business establishment to conduct, maintain, operate or engage in the business of conducting entertainment as described herein without first obtaining a license in the manner prescribed herein. 
(Code 1994, § 6-38; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-99. - Application and fees. 
(a)  Application form . The license shall be granted by the city council. Application for said license shall be made on a form containing such information as determined by the city clerk to be pertinent. 
(b)  Exclusions . Public and private schools, churches and/or religious functions in the form of entertainment as described herein and held on a school or church property are excluded from the application and license process. 
(c)  Fee . The fee for each license, or the renewal, if applicable, granted to the individual or business establishment shall not exceed $100.00 per occurrence. 
(d)  Exceptions . The fee for such license as described herein may be waived, when the entertainment provided is sponsored by a religious, charity or nonprofit group. 
(Code 1994, § 6-40; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-100. - Issuance. 
(a)  All petitions for licenses shall be heard and determined by the city council. A license shall be issued to an individual or business establishment, for either an individual event or for a period of up to one year, only after the city council is satisfied that the applicant is a fit and proper person or business enterprise and shall have complied with all requirements set forth herein and set forth in the Rhode Island General Laws that apply including, but not limited to, an inspection to be made of the premises to be licensed and is satisfied that such premises complies with all laws, rules and regulations of the building official and fire division. As evidence of this, written certification is issued to the applicant by the building official and fire division. Said certification must be issued prior to final action of applicant's application. A license shall be effective for a term commencing on December 1 of a given year through November 30 of the following year or for the time approved by the city council. 
(b)  No license authorized by this division shall be issued or renewed unless the building official of the city and the fire division of the city shall inspect the premises and certify that the premises comply with all state and local requirements. 
(Code 1994, § 6-39; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-101. - Capacity. 
    If only certain rooms within the premises are to be utilized for entertainment, said applicant shall be required to indicate on the application the location of each and every room or space which is to be used for such purpose and the determination as to the maximum capacity of patrons shall be determined by the city fire division. 
(Code 1994, § 6-41; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-102. - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
    In order to be granted a license, the applicant must obtain a certificate of zoning compliance from the code enforcement officer which states that the type of entertainment proposed is permitted in the zoning district where the premises is located. 
(Code 1994, § 6-42; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-103. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferred or assigned to any individual or business establishment or used by any individual or business establishment other than the licensee to whom it was issued, nor shall such license be used on any premises other than the premises stated in such license. 
(Code 1994, § 6-43; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-104. - Changes in corporate licenses. 
    If, during the term of the licensing period, one or more directors, stockholders, or officers of a corporate or members of a limited liability company license are substituted or added, each substituted or added director, stockholder, or officer shall, within five days of such change, file with the city clerk, an application for an approval of the change on such forms as are prescribed by the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 6-44; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-105. - Suspension or revocation. 
    After reasonable notice and a hearing, the city council shall have the right and authority to impose a fine, suspend or revoke any license granted under this division. Cause shall include but not be limited to, instances when an establishment is shown to have become disorderly or to have otherwise adversely affected the quiet enjoyment or quality of life of residents or when state or local law has been violated. 
(Code 1994, § 6-46; Ord. of 5-30-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Secs. 6-106-6-123. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL AND ELECTRONIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND AMUSEMENT CENTERS, BILLIARD OR POOL ROOMS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Bowling alleys, billiard tables and shooting galleries, G.L. 1956, § 5-2-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-124. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement game means any mechanical, electric, video and electronic machine or device used or designed to be operated for entertainment or as a game by the insertion of money, tokens or other articles or by paying money to have it activated; such term shall include but not be limited to marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines, video or computer type games, electronically operated or displayed games, air games and all operations similar thereto; such term shall not include any rides, bowling alleys, pool tables or any device maintained within a residence for the use of occupants thereof and their guests. 
    Game room means any structure or portion of a structure or place containing four or more amusement games. 
    Pool/billiard table means any oblong cloth-covered table with raised cushioned edges with or without side pockets on which the game commonly known as billiard or pool is played. 
    Pool or billiards room means any building or room where four or more tables are kept for the use and entertainment of the public. 
(Code 1994, § 6-86; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 2; Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-125. - Operation of game rooms, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards rooms. 
    Standards for the operation of game rooms, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards rooms shall be as follows: 
(1)  The owner and operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall comply with all provisions of law, ordinance, rule or regulation relating to the conduct of business and the use and maintenance of the premises. 
(2)  The owner and operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall cause the game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room license to be posted at all times in a conspicuous place on the premises. 
(3)  The owner and operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not permit such premises to be overcrowded. 
(4)  The owner and operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room and the members, officers, directors and holders of ten percent or more of the stock of any corporation, partnership or association owning or operating a game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not have been convicted of any crime that has a reasonable relationship to fitness to own or operate any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room. 
(5)  The owner and operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall maintain good order on the premises at all times. The lack of good order on the premises of a game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall include but shall not be limited to the following: 
a.  Fighting and rowdy behavior; 
b.  Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, except within premises licensed for on-premises consumption of those beverages; 
c.  Gambling; 
d.  Permitting the use of marijuana or any controlled substance, the possession of which is prohibited by law. 
(6)  The owner or operator of any game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not permit an amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room therein to be played or operated after 10:00 p.m. by a person under the age of 16 years unless accompanied by and under the supervision of a parent or other guardian over the age of 18. 
(7)  The owner or operator of a game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not allow it to be open or used unless it is under the control of and supervision by a person at least 18 years of age who shall ensure that it is operated in compliance with law. 
(8)  The owner and operator of a game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not allow it to be open or the amusement games, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room therein played on any day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. during the months of July and August; except that, when school is in session, such prohibited hours will become 10:00 p.m. to 2:30 p.m. 
(9)  The owner and operator of a game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not allow more amusement games, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room than the number permitted in the license to be located therein at any time. 
(Code 1994, § 6-88; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(f); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-126. - Operation of amusement games, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room. 
    Standards for the operation of amusement games, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall be as follows: 
(1)  The owner of any amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room within the city shall comply with all provisions of law, ordinance, rule or regulation applicable thereto and relating to the conduct of the business in connection with which the game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room is used and the use and maintenance of the premises where it is located. 
(2)  The owner of the game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall maintain good order on the premises at all times. The lack of good order on the premises shall include but not be limited to the following: 
a.  Fighting and rowdy behavior; 
b.  Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, except upon premises licensed for on-premises consumption thereof; 
c.  Gambling; 
d.  Permitting the use of marijuana or any controlled substance, the possession of which is prohibited by the law. 
(3)  The owner of an amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not permit it to be played or operated after 10:00 p.m. by a person under the age of 16 years unless accompanied by and under the supervision of a parent or other guardian over the age of 18. 
(4)  The owner of an amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall not allow it to be available for use or used unless it is under the control of and supervision by a person at least 18 years of age, who shall ensure that it is operated in compliance with law. 
(5)  No cash awards shall be offered or given in any contest, tournament, league or individual play on any amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room, and no such game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall be permitted to operate if such game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room delivers or may readily be converted to deliver to the player any piece of money, coin, slug or token. 
(6)  No credit, allowance, check, slug, token or anything of value shall be offered or given to any player of any amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room as a result of plays made thereon. 
(Code 1994, § 6-89; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(g); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-127. - Inspections. 
    The premises of all game rooms, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room in the city shall be subject to inspection by any peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or any police officer. Any other premises in the city containing amusement games, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall be subject to inspection by any peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or any police officer. 
(Code 1994, § 6-90; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(h), (i); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-128. - Gambling devices prohibited. 
    No machine or device, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room which would constitute a gambling device as defined by G.L. 1956, § 11-19-18, or any other section of the general laws, shall be licensed by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 6-106; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(e); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Secs. 6-129-6-154. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-155. - Required. 
    Every person maintaining or operating a game room or amusement device, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room shall first obtain an annual license from the city. 
(Code 1994, § 6-101; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 3; Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-156. - Application requirements. 
(a)  Types of establishments that may apply for mechanical and electronic amusement device, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room licenses include any businesses whose primary business is entertainment or recreation during their regular business hours. 
(b)  An application form for amusement game or game room, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room licenses shall require the following information: 
(1)  Name, age and address of applicant; and names and addresses of officers if a corporation or association; 
(2)  The place where each machine or device, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at such place; and 
(3)  A description of the machine or machines, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room to be covered by the license, the mechanical features and the serial numbers thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 6-103; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(a), (b); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-157. - Qualifications of licensee. 
    No license under this division shall be issued to any individual unless he is over the age of 18 years and not an illegal alien. 
(Code 1994, § 6-102; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(c); Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-158. - Term; fee. 
    Licenses granted under this division shall continue for a term not exceeding one year upon payment of the currently required amount for the license for a game room or amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room and any renewal thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 6-104; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 4; Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-159. - Display. 
    Every machine, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room on display or operated under the terms of this division shall require a license, and such license shall be displayed on each machine, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room so licensed or in a conspicuous place at such location. 
(Code 1994, § 6-105; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(d); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-160. - Payment of property tax prerequisite to issuance. 
    No license under this division shall be issued or renewed until such times as the personal property tax assessed against the game room or amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room owned or kept according to the provisions of this division have been paid. 
(Code 1994, § 6-107; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 8; Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-161. - Issuance; effective and expiration dates. 
    All applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the city clerk and shall become effective on December 1, and shall expire on November 30 of each year. All such licenses shall be issued by the city clerk after the application for such license shall have been approved by the city council and upon payment of the required fees and provided that all state and city requirements have been made. 
(Code 1994, § 6-108; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 6; Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-162. - Suspension or revocation. 
    If the licensee shall permit the place where any game room or amusement game, pool tables, billiards tables, pool rooms and billiards room is located to become disorderly so as to annoy and disturb reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities inhabiting, working or residing in the neighborhood thereof, or shall permit any of the laws of the state or the city to be violated therein, in addition to any punishment or penalty which may be prescribed by statute for such offense, the licensee may be summoned before the city council, where the licensee and the witnesses for and against the licensee may be heard, and if it shall be made to appear to the satisfaction of the city council hearing such charges that the licensee has permitted to be done any of the things hereinbefore in this division mentioned, the city council may suspend or revoke such license or enter other orders thereon. 
(Code 1994, § 6-109; Ord. of 9-13-1982, § 5(j); Ord. of 6-4-2001; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Secs. 6-163-6-192. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-223. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a theater for the purpose of exhibiting moving pictures without a license from the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 14-79; Code 1994, § 6-176; Ord. of 10-14-2015 , § 4) 
Sec. 6-224. - Application; issuance.
