State Law reference- Relief of injured and deceased police officers, G.L. 1956, § 45-19-1 et seq.; appeals from police department, G.L. 1956, § 45-20-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DIVISION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-19. - Composition. 
    The police division of the department of public safety of the city shall consist of the superior officers appointed under the provisions of the Charter and as many police patrol officers as the director of public safety deems necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 21-1; Code 1994, § 22-26; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-20. - Hiring procedures. 
(a)  Legislative findings. 
(1)  It is the policy of the city to provide high-quality police service to our community. Quality policing is provided by professional, well-trained individuals working together. Selecting the best people to be our community's police is essential to the make-up of the police department and the fundamental aim of a recruiting program. A proactive, positive approach to police recruiting is necessary to attract quality applicants representative of the demographics of the city. Recruiting is conducted when needed to maintain service strength. 
(2)  It is the policy of the city to identify and employ the best-qualified individuals to perform the tasks and functions of the police department without regard to race, color, religion, sex, age, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, socioeconomic status or mental, physical, developmental, or sensory disability. The department prohibits discrimination against any person in recruitment, appointment, training, promotion, retention, discipline, or any other aspect of personnel administration for reasons of political or religious opinions, affiliations, or because of race, color, national origin, physical disability or age, except where specific age or physical requirements constitute a bonafide occupational qualification necessary to properly and efficiently perform the functions of the job. 
(3)  It is the policy of the city to actively encourage women and traditionally under-represented populations to apply for employment in all positions within the police department. All persons should have equal opportunities in recruitment, selection, appointment, promotion, training, discipline and related areas. 
(b)  The director of human resources shall advertise through statewide printed media and the subsequent methods of community outreach that applications are being accepted for the position of police officer grade II. Notice will be given to applicants of the time and place where competitive exams will be held. 
(1)  Applications will be made available online to create better accessibility for potential candidates. 
(2)  Demographically under-represented and female officers will be depicted in the law enforcement role in department publications whenever possible to encourage potential female and demographically under-represented candidates. 
(3)  Female officers or officers who are demographically under-represented within the department, whenever possible, will actively encourage recruitment of potential candidates. 
(4)  The police department will participate in information sessions, and career fairs to encourage potential candidates; when possible utilizing female and demographically under-represented officers. 
(5)  The police department will build upon relationships with high schools, colleges, and universities to attract potential candidates. 
(6)  The police department will work with groups in the community representing the community's diversity to build relationships and encourage potential candidates. 
(7)  Advertising will be formatted in all languages that are spoken by at least ten percent of city residents as determined by the United States Census Bureau. 
(8)  Advertising will include print, web and radio broadcasts on local media outlets. 
(9)  Advertising will be distributed to local area businesses in targeted areas of the city. 
(c)  All statements of police officer applicants relative to eligibility are subject to verification by authentic proof thereof, and applicants shall authorize the director of human resources to make legitimate investigations as to residency, citizenship, education and/or evidence of eligibility. 
(d)  Any person who has ever been convicted of a crime or has been placed on a term of probation, or has received a deferred sentence, or a filing after entering a plea constituting an admission to a complaint, information or indictment may be ineligible for appointment to the police department. 
(e)  No person shall be appointed unless they are a citizen of the United States. All applicants must be high school graduates or have received a G.E.D. certificate and have an associate degree or 60 or more college or junior college credits. An exception may be made to the requirement of an associate degree or 60 or more college or junior college credits if an applicant has completed their enlistment period and has been honorably discharged from the U.S. Armed Forces or can document a minimum of one year fulltime service in the field of law enforcement. 
(f)  No applicant for the position of police officer may be younger than 18 years of age on the date of application. 
(g)  An applicant's eligibility for the position of police officer grade II shall be established by the following criteria: 
(1)  The human resources department shall make available an application form which prospective candidates must complete without the aid or assistance of any other person. Statements that are materially false shall result in disqualification or if discovered after appointment shall be cause for dismissal. 
(2)  Applicants shall be examined by their physician to determine their ability to perform a physical fitness exam without substantial risk of injury. Results of such examination shall be forwarded to the city on a form supplied by the city. 
(3)  A physical fitness exam shall be required of all applicants. This exam shall be consistent with the state municipal police training academy standards. The physical fitness requirements shall be conducted by the police department with the assistance of one or more certified physical fitness specialists selected from a list provided by the state municipal police training academy. Each candidate participating shall be scored on a pass/fail basis for each of the required activities. 
(4)  Candidates who have passed the physical examination shall be required to take a written examination. Such examination shall be prepared and scored by an independent examination service selected by the director of human resources. The maximum score for the written examination shall be 40, provided that an additional four points shall be awarded for those who have established documented legal residency in the city for at least one year prior to application to the department, an additional two points shall be awarded for any veteran honorably discharged from the U.S. Armed Forces, and an additional four points shall be awarded for any person fluent in any second language as spoken by at least ten percent of city residents as determined by the United States Census Bureau for a final, total maximum score for the written examination of 50. 
(5)  An oral examination is to be given to the top 25 scores on the written examination by a four member board consisting of the following, or his or her designee: the public safety director, the chief/colonel of the police department, the director of human resources and a woman or demographically under-represented police officer from the city police department as designated by the police union of the city. The oral examination shall be recorded on video. The oral examination shall consist of questions designed to test past experience, personality, alertness, confidence, qualifications, diversity awareness, professional bearing, and judgment of the applicant. The members of the board are required to evaluate the applicant on a zero to ten point system for each of the ten interview questions. At no time may any two board members scoring be more than two points apart per question. The candidate's total score for the oral examination shall be computed by dividing the combined scores of the examiners by eight. The maximum score for the oral examination shall be 50. 
(6)  Candidates who attain the highest combined total scores under subsections (4) through (5) of this section shall be placed on the eligibility list numerically. 
(7)  At the discretion of the chief of the police department, candidates on the eligibility list may be afforded a physical examination by the city physician or a physician appointed by the city, and will be required to undergo psychological testing and a comprehensive background investigation. If any of the candidates fail to qualify physically or psychologically or as a result of their background investigation, as determined by the director of public safety, they shall be ineligible for referral to the personnel board for hiring and removed from the eligibility list. The next qualified candidate, at the discretion of the chief of the police department, shall be selected for the physical and psychological examinations and a background investigation. After the required number of candidates have been determined to pass the physical and psychological examinations and background investigation, the chief of the police department shall make a recommendation of hiring from the candidates who are ranked one, two or three to the personnel board who shall make the appointment to the police department from the eligibility list. 
(8)  The eligibility list shall be valid for a maximum of two years from the date of the personnel board's decision, unless the director of public safety grants a six-month extension, and shall extinguish sooner upon no qualified candidates remaining on the list. 
(h)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the director of public safety shall have the authority to establish a procedure for the hiring of a lateral transfer applicant, defined as a police officer in good standing, with at least three years experience. 
(Code 1994, § 22-27; Ord. of 4-14-1993, § 19-37; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2); Ord. of 5-12-2008(2); Ord. of 9-28-2015 , § 1; Ord. of 12-11-2017(1) , § 1) 
Sec. 22-21. - Filling of vacancies. 
(a)  Policies and procedures relating to the promotions for the rank of sergeant, lieutenant, captain, and major shall be governed by the relevant provisions in the collective bargaining agreement between the police union and the city. 
(Code 1994, § 22-28; Ord. of 4-14-1993, § 19-37.1; Ord. of 5-12-1993(1), § 19-38; Ord. of 8-4-1998; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2); Ord. of 9-28-2015 , § 1) 
Sec. 22-22. - Course reimbursement. 
(a)  Consistent with G.L. 1956, § 42-28.1-1 et seq., any newly hired fulltime police officer of the city police department shall be entitled to reimbursement of his/her eligible expenses incurred by taking courses leading to an associate's degree in law enforcement or criminal justice. 
(b)  The term "eligible expenses" includes the cost of tuition, books and supplies. 
(c)  Reimbursement for eligible expenses shall be limited to that amount which is charged by the Community College of Rhode Island per semester regardless of the number of courses taken in a semester. 
(Ord. of 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 22-23. - Conduct of members and employees. 
    The members of the police division, both civilian and sworn, shall not engage in any other business or employment, unless approved by the office of the colonel/chief of police, and they shall perform all such duties as are or may be required of them by the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. They shall severally obey their superior officers and shall faithfully conform to and observe all rules and regulations made for the management of the division. 
(Code 1973, § 21-2; Code 1994, § 22-29; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-24. - Colonel/chief, major/deputy chief or captains to be complainants. 
    The colonel/chief of police and in his absence the major/deputy chief of police and the captains shall, respectively, in order, severally be complainants under any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 21-3; Code 1994, § 22-30; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-25. - Station house. 
    The station house shall be in the charge of the ranking officer on regular duty and such officer shall be responsible for the enforcement at such times of the rules and regulations for the government of the station and for the conduct of the officers under his command. In case of enforced absence, such ranking officer shall detail an officer to have charge of the station. The officer in charge shall receive into his custody and safely keep all persons arrested. 
(Code 1973, § 21-4; Code 1994, § 22-31; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-26. - Fines, fees, penalties and compensation received by police. 
    All fees, fines and penalties received by any member of the police division and all compensation received for services rendered in an official capacity or within the hours prescribed for official duty shall be immediately accounted for and paid over to the colonel/chief of police, who shall pay the same over to the director of finance as required by the Charter. The colonel/chief shall also enter the amount so received, the name of the policeman from whom received and the case in which the same was so received in a book which the colonel/chief of police is hereby required to keep for that purpose. In the same book the colonel/chief of police shall enter, in like manner, all fees, fines, penalties and compensation received by himself. He shall, at least once in each month, present such book to the director of finance, who is hereby required to examine the same and the items thereof and who, if he finds it correct, shall certify accordingly and state the monthly sum thereof; provided, however, that the colonel/chief of police shall be allowed to retain from such sum so much thereof as will enable him to have on hand the sum of $25.00 to meet the incidental expenses of his office, which disbursements shall always be accounted for subsequently; provided further, that members of the permanent police who receive fees for attendance upon the district, superior or supreme court shall be entitled to retain such fees to their own use as reimbursement for the expenses incident to such attendance. 
(Code 1973, § 21-5; Code 1994, § 22-32; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-27. - Monthly report of colonel/chief. 
    The colonel/chief of police shall, once in each month, present to the city council a report showing the condition of the police division, the work done during the month preceding the report, the amount paid over to the director of finance under the provisions of section 22-26, and any suggestions respecting the division which he may deem in the interests of the city to require. 
(Code 1973, § 21-6; Code 1994, § 22-33; Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-28. - Removal of colonel/chief from collective bargaining unit. 
    No colonel/chief of police shall be a member of the collective bargaining unit. 
(Code 1994, § 22-34; Ord. of 3-7-1994; Ord. of 8-31-2004(4); Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-29. - Regulations for the employment of the colonel/chief of police. 
(a)  A colonel/chief of police of the city, appointed under the regulations of this Code, shall be retained either under an employment contract not to exceed 60 months, or as an at-will employee who may be terminated at any time, without cause. 
(b)  Every contract shall commence on the second Monday in January. 
(Code 1994, § 22-35; Ord. of 11-8-2004(2); Ord. of 6-25-2007(2)) 
Sec. 22-30. - Processing fee for application to carry a concealed pistol or revolver. 
    Pursuant to R.I.G.L. § 11-47-11 et seq., the chief of police is the authorized authority for issuance of a license to carry a pistol or revolver and is responsible to conduct appropriate investigation into an applicant's qualifications and needs for said license. The chief of police shall adopt a written policy, in conformity with applicable state and federal laws, for the procedure in the issuance of such a license, and the processing fee for all applications shall be $160.00. 
(Ord. of 3-20-2013(1) ) 
Secs. 22-31-22-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE OFFICERS' PENSION 

Sec. 22-60. - List and fund created. 
    The city council hereby creates and establishes a pension list and pension fund for officers and members of the permanent police division of the city and for all who shall become members of the division. 
(Code 1973, § 21-7; Code 1994, § 22-56) 
Sec. 22-61. - Eligibility. 
(a)  Upon recommendation of the board of pensions and retirement, the city council may place upon the pension list permanent members of the paid police division who: 
(1)  Request to be placed on non-service connected disability by reason of age, physical or mental infirmity, which renders the member totally or partially permanently disabled; provided, however, that no member of the division shall be eligible for a non-service connected disability pension unless he or she served at least five years; provided further, that no member of the division shall be placed upon the pension list until there is presented to the board of pensions and retirement a certificate from a physician approved by the city that the member is totally or partially permanently disabled. 
(2)  Request to be placed on service-connected disability by reason of injuries sustained or illness incurred while in the performance of duty which renders the member totally or partially permanently disabled. No member of the division shall be granted a service-connected disability pension and placed upon the pension list until there is presented to the board of pensions and retirement a certificate from a physician approved by the city that he or she is unfit to perform active duty. It is the express intent and purpose of this provision for the service-connected disability pension benefits received by a member to be benefits paid in lieu of workers' compensation benefits. 
(3)  The determination of disability from any cause, whether service connected or non-service connected shall be made upon the basis of reports on examinations made by three physicians consisting of the treating physician, a physician selected by the city, and a third physician to be selected by the other two physicians. A majority decision by the selected physicians must be reached with regard to 
a.  Determination of disability; and 
b.  Whether the disability is total and permanent or partial and permanent. 
The member shall be provided a written determination of the decision within 60 days after the date that the city has received all three physicians' reports. If the majority decision is that the member has sustained a total or partial permanent disability, the physician appointed by the city shall so certify to the board of pensions and retirement in accordance with paragraph (1). 
(4)  In the event there is no duly constituted board of pensions and retirement, recommendation for placement on the pension list shall be made by the director of personnel and the administrative and finance officer to the city council. 
(b)  For the purpose of this provision, the city shall determine whether a member is totally and permanently disabled utilizing the same standards as the Social Security Administration, which includes the presumptive total and permanent disabilities set forth by the Social Security Administration. 
(c)  A member who has been placed on the pension list for service-connected total and permanent disability shall receive disability retirement benefits for life. 
(d)  A member who has been placed on the pension list for service-connected partial and permanent disability, shall be placed on a regular pension when he or she reaches social security retirement age, calculated in accordance with the collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time the member became disabled. 
(Code 1973, § 21-8; Code 1994, § 22-57; Ord. of 8-10-2016(1) , § 2) 
Sec. 22-62. - Request to have name placed on list. 
    Any permanent member of the police division who has been regularly employed as a member of the division for at least 25 years and who has attained the age set forth in the collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time the request is made, may in writing request the board of pensions and retirement to place his or her name on such pension list and, if the board shall grant such request, the name of the member shall be placed upon the list. If the member has been regularly employed for 25 years and has not attained the age set forth in the collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time the request is made, the member may be placed on the list and elect to defer the payment of pension benefits until he reaches said age; provided, however, that if said member elects to receive pension benefits immediately, the amount of said benefits will be reduced by an early retirement factor, as actuarially determined. 
(Code 1973, § 21-9; Code 1994, § 22-58; Ord. of 8-10-2016(1) , § 2) 
Sec. 22-63. - Members subject to rules of division and to recall to temporary active duty. 
    Members of the pension list shall be subject to all rules of the police division as to conduct. The chief of police may at any time call upon members on the pension list for temporary regular police duty, and for such service they shall receive full pay at the rate then paid regular members of the division for similar work. During the term of such temporary active police duty, such pensioned members shall not be entitled to any compensation from the pension fund. 
(Code 1973, § 21-10; Code 1994, § 22-59) 
Sec. 22-64. - Payments into fund. 
    The director of finance is hereby authorized and directed to place in the pension fund: 
(1)  One percent of the annual salary or wages due each permanent member of the paid police division, to be deducted by him from each payroll. 
(2)  All fines and penalties imposed upon members of the police division for violations of the rules and regulations of the division and certified to him by the chief of police. It is hereby made a duty of the chief to communicate such fines and penalties to the director of finance. 
(3)  All sums charged against any of the members absent from duty where no substitute has been employed in such member's place, provided that such absence was not caused by illness. It is hereby made a duty of the chief of police to communicate such charges to the director of finance. 
(4)  All donations, contributions and receipts from any source that may be made or received on account of or for the benefit of the fund. 
(Code 1973, § 21-11; Code 1994, § 22-60) 
Sec. 22-65. - Additional appropriations when fund insufficient. 
    Whenever the policemen's pension fund shall be insufficient to pay the pensions to the members entitled thereto, the city council shall appropriate from time to time such additional sums as may be required to carry out the intent and provisions of this division. 
(Code 1973, § 21-12; Code 1994, § 22-61) 
Sec. 22-66. - Custodian of fund; investments. 
    The director of finance shall be the custodian of the policemen's pension fund, which he shall keep separate and apart from other funds. He may invest, reinvest and change the form of investment of the fund, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 21-13; Code 1994, § 22-62) 
Sec. 22-67. - Amount of benefits. 
    Any permanent member of the paid police division placed on the pension list shall receive thereafter during his lifetime, unless otherwise provided, a pension equivalent to one-half of the compensation he was receiving at the time he was placed upon the list, to be paid weekly to those entitled thereto; provided, however, that any paid member of the police division who has served at least 15 years on the paid police division shall receive thereafter a minimum pension of $25.00 per week or, as provided in this section, one-half of the compensation he was receiving at the time he was placed upon the list, whichever is the greater. 
(Code 1973, § 21-14; Code 1994, § 22-63) 
Sec. 22-68. - Assessments need not be paid after name placed on list. 
    A member on the pension fund list shall not be required to pay any assessment to the fund from the date his name is placed upon the pension list. 
(Code 1973, § 21-15; Code 1994, § 22-64) 
Sec. 22-69. - Refund of contributions on cessation of membership. 
    Any member of the police division who shall resign or be discharged therefrom shall thereupon be entitled to any payments theretofore made by him to the fund. 
(Code 1973, § 21-16; Code 1994, § 22-65) 
Sec. 22-70. - Payments not transferable or subject to attachment. 
    The pension payments provided by this article shall not be transferable nor subject to attachment and shall be paid to the member entitled thereto; except, that they may be regulated and arranged by the city council and paid so as to be best appropriated to the use and benefit of the person entitled to them. 
(Code 1973, § 21-17; Code 1994, § 22-66) 
State Law reference- Exemption of pension fund from attachment or other process, G.L. 1956, § 9-26-5. 
Sec. 22-71. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board of pensions and retirement, subject to approval of the city council, is hereby empowered to make such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this division as may be deemed best for governing the pension list and payments provided for by this division. 
(Code 1973, § 21-18; Code 1994, § 22-67) 
Secs. 22-72-22-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE PROTECTION SERVICES 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions; interpretation. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dwelling unit means a structure or portion thereof providing independent and complete cooking, living, sleeping and toilet facilities for a group of persons living as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Excessive police response means each police response in excess of five to a single dwelling unit in a residential property. 
    Mobile home means a detached single dwelling unit fabricated at a factory and capable of being transported to location of use on its own chassis and wheels, identified by a model number and serial number by its manufacturer, and designed primarily for placement on an impermanent foundation. 
    Owner, when used in reference to a residential property, means the record owner of the residential property as shown in the real property records. 
    Police response means that one or more police officers goes to a residential property in response to a call for assistance, a complaint, an emergency or a potential emergency; provided, that the term "police response" does not include a response to: 
(1)  Receipt of false information, unless the false information was provided by an occupant or owner of the residential property. 
(2)  A false alarm, unless the false alarm was caused, permitted or allowed by an occupant or owner of the residential property in violation. 
(3)  A call involving potential child neglect, potential domestic violence, or potential stalking. 
    Residential property means a parcel, tract or lot shown as an individual unit on the most recent plat of record that contains one or more dwelling units, and a mobile home. 
(Code 1994, § 22-76; Ord. of 6-1-2004, § I) 
Sec. 22-102. - Fee for police protection services. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a residential property shall pay the municipality a fee of $300.00 per occurrence in excess of five police responses to the residential property during a calendar year. 
(b)  The owner of a residential property shall be liable for the fee established by subsection (a) of this section only if: 
(1)  The municipality has notified the owner in writing that the fee will apply to any excessive police responses to the residential property during the calendar year. 
(2)  The time allowed for appropriate corrective action has expired. 
(3)  The owner has not taken appropriate corrective action. 
(c)  If a residential property has more than one owner, all owners shall be jointly and severally liable for any fee imposed under this section. 
(d)  For residential property owned as a condominium, a fee based on excessive police responses to a single dwelling unit shall be assessed against the owner of the dwelling unit. 
(Code 1994, § 22-77; Ord. of 6-1-2004, § II) 
Sec. 22-103. - Notice to property owner. 
(a)  The municipality may notify the owner of a residential property in writing there have been five police responses in the current calendar year to a single dwelling unit in the residential property. 
(b)  A notice under this section shall be given in a manner that is reasonably calculated to provide actual notice to the owner of the residential property. At a minimum, the notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the mailing address of the owner as shown on the municipality's real property tax records, and if the residential property has a different street address, to that street address. The municipality also shall give notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, at another address where it appears more likely that the owner will receive actual notice at the address. Such other address may include, without limitation, an address identified from the telephone directory, public records, or prior police contacts with the residential property or the owner. The notice also shall be posted at the principal entrance to the entrance to the residential property. 
(c)  The notice shall: 
(1)  Identify the residential property that is the subject of the notice by street address and legal description, and identify the dwelling unit to which the police responses have been made if there is more that one dwelling unit in the residential property. 
(2)  State that there have been five police responses to a dwelling unit in the residential property during the current calendar year. 
(3)  State that if the owner does not take appropriate corrective action, the owner will be liable for a fee for each excessive police response to the residential property during the calendar year. 
(4)  State the amount of the fee per excessive police response to the residential property. 
(5)  State the name and telephone number of a representative of the city to contact concerning the notice. 
(Code 1994, § 22-78; Ord. of 6-1-2004, § III) 
Sec. 22-104. - Corrective action. 
(a)  An owner of a residential property shall have 30 days from the date of mailing of the notice to promptly take appropriate corrective action in response to the notice. Appropriate corrective action shall be action that reasonably would be expected to correct the cause of the police responses to the residential property, and may include, without limitation, written notice to quit. 
(b)  There shall be no fee for additional police responses to the residential property that is the subject of the notice during the 30-day period allowed under subsection (a) of this section if the owner takes appropriate corrective action during the 30-day period. The owner shall be considered to have taken appropriate corrective action if there are no additional police responses to the residential property from the end of the 30-day period until the earlier of the: 
(1)  End of the calendar year; or 
(2)  The date 90 days after the end of the 30-day period as allowed under this section. 
(Code 1994, § 22-79; Ord. of 6-1-2004, § 4) 
Sec. 22-105. - Lien on property. 
(a)  The fee imposed is a lien on the residential property to which there have been an excessive number of police responses. 
(b)  The lien becomes effective upon the recording of a notice of the lien that describes the residential property that is the subject of the lien, states the amount of fees for which the lien has been recorded, and states that the lien has been recorded pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1994, § 22-80; Ord. of 6-1-2004, § 5) 
Secs. 22-106-22-123. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - POLICE DETAILS 

Sec. 22-124. - Assignment requests for events or projects; procedures. 
(a)  Any and all requests for detail police officers shall be made through the police department detail officer. 
(b)  The chief of police, or his designee, in accordance with the collective bargaining agreement between the city and the FOP Lodge #2, shall have the power and authority to determine and assign the number of police detail officers/vehicles to any projects or any other special detail assignments within the city. 
(c)  The chief of police, or his designee, shall review all projects and assignments within the city to determine the necessity of any assignments of officers to foster public safety and the safety of the officers. 
(d)  Any and all parties requesting police details shall be required to comply with the recommendation of the chief of police, or his designee, and all other provisions of this chapter. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the chief of police, or his designee, shall have the full power and authority to determine the necessity of any detail within the city. 
(Ord. of 6-25-2007(1)) 
Sec. 22-125. - Payments by responsible party. 
(a)  The city shall be reimbursed for any and all sums paid to any officer in accordance with the detail payment schedule in effect. Payment shall be made by the responsible party in accordance with the schedule of charges in effect by the city. 
(b)  Prior to the furnishing of any detail officers, the chief of police, or his designee, shall require the party deemed responsible for the event or project to acknowledge its financial obligation to the city. Further, the acknowledging party shall be responsible to pay the city administrative costs of four dollars per hour and vehicle maintenance costs of $12.00 per hour for expenses incurred by the city. These costs are in addition to the wages required to be paid to the members of FOP Lodge #2 pursuant to their official detail rates for officers. 
(c)  All parties deemed responsible for the event or project shall make payment to the city finance department directly. Payment must be made within 45 days of the date of the work; otherwise a 25 percent late fee will immediately be assessed and a 11/2 percent interest rate per month will accrue on the unpaid balance. These fees will be assessed by the finance department. 
(d)  All detail monies will be paid to the officers in accordance with the normal city payroll system. All applicable taxes will be withheld by the city. The officers will be paid in the next complete payroll cycle following the detail in accordance with the current payroll system. 
(e)  The cost of any litigation with respect to payment will be borne by the party deemed responsible for the event or project. 
(f)  The finance director shall set up a special revenue account for the police department. 
(Ord. of 6-25-2007(1)) 
Chapter 24 - LIBRARY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Free public libraries, G.L. 1956, § 29-4-1 et seq. 

Sec. 24-1. - Appropriated to use of inhabitants; name. 
    The free public library acquired from the city fire district shall continue to be appropriated to the use of all the inhabitants of the city under such rules and regulations as may be from time to time adopted by the board of trustees of the library. Such library shall be called "the free public library of the city." 
(Code 1973, § 2-14; Code 1994, § 24-1) 
Sec. 24-2. - Meetings of board of trustees; annual report. 
    The board of trustees of the public library shall meet not less than four times per year and more often if they deem it necessary. They shall make a report to the city council on or before December 1 in each year of their proceedings during the year preceding the report, of the condition of the library and extent of its public use, the additions to the library, and its receipts and expenses during the year, and may make such suggestions and give such further information relating to the library as the board may deem expedient. 
(Code 1973, § 2-16; Code 1994, § 24-2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to appointment of library trustees, G.L. 1956, § 29-4-5. 
Sec. 24-3. - Fines and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall take or borrow any book or other library property from any of the libraries or collections of public libraries within the city, primarily subsidized by local or state funds, and who, upon neglect to return the same within the time required and specified in the bylaws, rules or regulations of the public library owning such property, after receiving notice in writing by the librarian or other proper custodian of the property that the same is overdue, shall upon further neglect to return the same within 60 days from the date of such notice be fined not more than $25.00, such fine to be for the use of the public library. A written or printed notice given personally or sent by mail to a last known or registered place of residence shall be considered sufficient notice under this section. In addition, if such book should be lost, destroyed or not returned, such person shall, within 60 days after being so notified, pay to the custodian the replacement value of such book, including all reasonable processing costs as determined by the governing board having jurisdiction. All library users shall be notified of the aforementioned penalties at the time they obtain or renew their library privileges. 
(b)  Whoever, without authority, with the intention of converting to his own or another's use, willfully conceals a book or other library property belonging to a public library within the city which is primarily subsidized by local or state funds, while still on the premises of such public library, or willfully or without authority removes a book or other library property from any of the public libraries or collections therein, shall be fined not more than $25.00, such fine to be for the use of the library, and shall be ordered to make restitution to the library in the full retail value of the books or library property. 
(Code 1994, § 24-4; Ord. of 10-5-1992) 
Chapter 26 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Malicious destruction of property or obstruction of lawful pursuits. 
    Every person who shall willfully and maliciously or mischievously injure or destroy the property of another, or obstruct the use of the property of another, or obstruct another in the prosecution of his lawful business or pursuits, in any manner, shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Code 1973, § 18-11; Code 1994, § 26-4; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 11-44-1. 
Sec. 26-2. - Airplane glue, sale or furnishing to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish, deliver, supply, lend or give any quantity of so-called toxic airplane glue to any minor unless first supplied with written permission from a parent or guardian of the minor requesting such minor to be sold, furnished or otherwise supplied with the toxic airplane glue. 
(Code 1973, § 18-1; Code 1994, § 26-12; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-3. - Child safety zone; sex offenders. 
    Sex offender registration, sex offender notification, child safety zones and violations related thereto shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 11-37 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 

(Ord. of 6-9-2008(2), §§ 1-5; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-4. - Juvenile curfew. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to: 
(1)  Promote the general welfare and protect the general public through the reduction of juvenile violence and crime within the city; 
(2)  Promote the safety and well-being of the city's youngest citizens, persons under the age of 18, whose life inexperience renders them particularly vulnerable to becoming participants in unlawful activities, particularly unlawful drug and gang activities, and to being victimized by older perpetrators of crime; and 
(3)  To help foster and strengthen parental responsibility for children. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of the article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular and words in the singular number include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Curfew hours refers to the hours between 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. on any day of the week. 
    Emergency refers to any unforeseen circumstances, or the status or condition resulting therefrom, requiring immediate action to safeguard life, limb, and property. The term includes, but is not limited to fires, natural disasters, automobile accidents, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment refers to any privately-owned place of business within the city operated for a profit, to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. With respect to such entertainment, the term "operator" shall mean any person, and any firm association, partnership (and the members or partners thereof) and/or any corporation (and the officers thereof) conducting or managing the establishment. 
    Juvenile or minor refers to any unemancipated, unmarried person under the age of 18. 
    Officer refers to a sworn police or other law enforcement officer charged with the duty of enforcing the laws of the state and/or the ordinances of the city. 
    Parent refers to: 
(1)  A person who is a minor's biological or adoptive parent and who has legal custody of a minor (including either parent, if custody is shared under court order or agreement); 
(2)  A person who is the biological or adoptive parent with whom a minor regularly resides; 
(3)  A stepparent; 
(4)  A person judicially appointed as a legal guardian of the minor; and/or 
(5)  A person 18 years of age or older standing in loco parentis (as indicated by the authorization of an individual listed in subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this definition, for the person to assume the care or physical custody of the child, or as indicated by any other circumstances). 
    Person refers to an individual, not to any association, corporation, or any other legal entity. 
    Public place refers to any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access, including, but not limited to: streets, highways, roads, sidewalks, alleys, avenues, parks, and/or the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment buildings, tenement houses, office buildings, transportation facilities, shops, stores, restaurants, parking lots, playgrounds, theatres, taverns, cafes, large gathering halls, and any similar areas that are open to the use of the public. 
    Remain refers to the actions: 
(1)  To linger or stay at or upon a public place; and/or 
(2)  To fail to leave a public place when requested to do so by an officer or by the owner, operator, or other person in control of that place. 
    Temporary care facility refers to a nonlocked, nonrestrictive shelter at which minors may wait, under visual supervision, to be retrieved by a parent. No minors waiting in such facility shall be handcuffed and/or secured (by handcuffs or otherwise) to any stationary object. 
(c)  Curfew for juveniles. It is unlawful for a juvenile to be in a public place within the city, to be in any motor vehicle operating or parked in a public place, or to be in or on the premises of any establishment within the city as follows: During every month of the year, juveniles may not be in a public place, as described in this subsection, during the hours of 9:00 p.m. through 5:00 a.m. on any day of the week 
(d)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The juvenile is accompanied by a parent; 
(2)  The juvenile is involved in an emergency; 
(3)  The juvenile is engaged in an employment activity, or is going to or returning home from such activity, without detour or stop; 
(4)  The juvenile is on the sidewalk directly abutting a place where he resides with a parent; 
(5)  The juvenile is attending an activity sponsored by a school, religious, or civic organization, by a public organization or agency, or by another similar organization or entity, which activity is supervised by adults, and/or the juvenile is going to or returning from such activity without detour or stop; 
(6)  The juvenile is on an errand at the direction of a parent, and the juvenile has in his possession a written note signed by the parent containing the following information: the name, signature, address, and telephone number of the parent authorizing the errand, the telephone number where the parent may be reached during the errand, the name of the juvenile, and a brief description of the errand, the juvenile's destination and the hours the juvenile is authorized to be engaged in the errand; 
(7)  The juvenile is involved in interstate travel through, or beginning or terminating in, the city; or 
(8)  The juvenile is exercising his First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and/or the right to assembly. 
A special curfew hour of 10:00 p.m. on Halloween night is hereby established for the trick or treat visitations. 
(e)  Parental responsibility. It shall be unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a juvenile knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow the juvenile to be in any public place within the city under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of this section. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a juvenile in that parent's legal custody. This requirement is intended to hold a neglectful or careless parent up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall, therefore, be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such juvenile. 
(f)  Establishment operator responsibility. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of an establishment, or for any person who is an employee thereof, to knowingly permit, allow or encourage a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours without his parent or guardian present. It shall be a defense to prosecution under this subsection that the operator or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present at the establishment without a parent or guardian after curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person (including a juvenile) to give a false name, address, or telephone number to any officer investigating a possible violation of this section. 
(g)  Vehicle operator responsibilities. It is unlawful for a person who is the owner or operator of any motor vehicle to knowingly permit, allow or encourage a violation of this section. 
(h)  Enforcement procedures. Before taking any enforcement action hereunder, an officer shall make an immediate investigation for the purpose of ascertaining whether of not the presence of a juvenile/minor in a public place, motor vehicle and/or establishment within the city during curfew hours is a violation of this section. The officer shall require the juvenile/minor to provide his name, age, address, telephone number, and how to contact his parent or guardian. In determining the age of the suspected juvenile and in the absence of convincing evidence such as a driver's license, passport, birth certificate, a police officer shall, in the first instance of a violation of this section, use the officer's best judgment in determining age. 
(1)  The officer shall issue the juvenile a written warning that the juvenile is in violation of this section and order the juvenile to go promptly home. 
(2)  Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience and may provide that the officer may transport the juvenile to a parent or guardian under appropriate circumstances. Circumstances prompting the transportation could include but not be limited to exact time of day, weather conditions, time of year, business or shift at time of juvenile encounter, etc. 
(3)  Notwithstanding subsection (h)(1) of this section, when a juvenile has received one previous written warning for violation of this section or an officer has reasonable grounds to believe that the juvenile has engaged in delinquent conduct, the procedure shall then be for the officer to take the juvenile to the police station where a parent or guardian and the juvenile shall be questioned. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility to the person designated there and then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial, and uniform enforcement, and recording, thus, make available experienced personnel and access to information and records for factual documentation. 
(4)  If a juvenile is detained pursuant to subsection (h)(3) of this section, once a parent or guardian has come to take charge of the juvenile, and the appropriate information has been recorded, the juvenile shall be released to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located or fails to take charge of the juvenile, then the juvenile shall be released to the juvenile authorities, except that in the extent that accordance with police regulations, approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the juvenile may temporarily be entrusted to an adult, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of a parent or guardian assume the responsibility of caring for the juvenile pending availability or arrival of a parent or guardian. 
(5)  Notwithstanding subsection (h)(4) of this section, if the situation dictates as determined by the officer-in-charge at the police station a juvenile may be transported to a temporary care facility for a period not to exceed the remainder of the curfew hours, so that his parents or guardian may retrieve the juvenile. 
(6)  In the case of a first violation of this section by a juvenile requiring the officer to issue a written warning, said written warning shall be either sent via mail or be hand delivered by an officer of the police department to the parent or guardian of the juvenile and shall advise said parent or guardian that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the article, including enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(7)  For the first violation of this section by an operator of an establishment who permits a juvenile to remain on the premises without a parent/guardian or without notifying the police department of the violator being in their establishment, an officer shall issue a written warning notice of violation with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of this section, including enforcement of operator responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(i)  Penalties. 
(1)  If, after the warning notice pursuant to subsection (h)(1) of this section of a first violation by a juvenile, a parent violates subection (e) of this section (in conjunction with a second violation by the juvenile), this shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. For the first offense by the parent, the fine shall be $100.00, and for each subsequent offense by a parent the fine shall increase by an additional $100.00, e.g., $200.00 for a second offense, $300.00 for a third offense. The judge of the municipal court of the city, upon finding a parent guilty, shall sentence the parent to pay this fine and the cost of prosecution. 
(2)  The parent/guardian having legal custody of a juvenile shall be liable for all costs incurred by the city for providing personnel to remain in the company of the juvenile who has been detained pursuant to subection (h)(3) of this section if the parent does not pick up the juvenile within one hour after receiving notice from the city that the city is detaining the juvenile for a curfew violation. The amount to be paid by the parent/guardian shall be based on an hourly wage and benefits of the city employee who is assigned to remain with the juvenile either at the police station or at a temporary care facility as specified in subsection (h)(5) of this section. 
(3)  The parent/guardian having legal custody of a juvenile shall be liable for any fine or condition of restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon a curfew violator, provided that the curfew violator has not paid the fine or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court, and further provided that the parent/guardian has been made a party defendant in all enforcement proceedings against the curfew violator and shall be served with all citations, summons, complaints, notices, and other documents required to be served on the curfew violator defendant. 
(4)  Any juvenile who shall violate any provisions of this section more than three times shall be reported to the juvenile authorities as a juvenile in need of supervision and the chief of police or his designee may proceed to file such charges with the family courts as deemed necessary. 
(5)  If, after the warning notice pursuant to subsection (h)(7) of this section of a violation of the article, an operator of an establishment violates subsection (f) of this section for a second time, this shall be treated as a first offense by the operator. For the first offense by an operator, the fine shall be $100.00, and for each subsequent offense by an operator the fine shall be increased by an additional $100.00, e.g., $200.00 for the second offense, $300.00 for the third offense. 
(j)  Continuing evaluation. The city council shall continue its evaluation and updating of this section. 
(k)  Notice. Notice of the existence of this section and of the curfew regulations established by it shall be posted in, on or about such public or quasi-public places as may be determined by the chief executive or the police department in order that the public may be constantly informed of the existence of this section and its regulations. 
(l)  Construction. 
(1)  The city attorney is hereby authorized to give advisory opinions in writing, which shall be binding and shall be adhered to by the police, until this section is amended in such respect, interpreting terms, phrases, parts or any provisions. Normally such advisory opinions shall be in response to good faith, signed letters addressed to the chief executive or to a member of the city council, questioning this section as: 
a.  Ambiguous; 
b.  Having a potentially chilling effect on constitutional rights specifically invoked; or 
c.  Otherwise invalid, in all three categories with respect to proposed conduct definitely described. 
(2)  This administrative remedy must be exhausted prior to presenting to any court a question in any of the three categories. The city council does not intend a result through the enforcement of this section that is absurd, impossible of execution or unreasonable. Council intends that this section be held inapplicable in such cases, if any, where its application would be unconstitutional under the Constitution of the state or the Constitution of the United States of America. 
(Ord. of 6-9-2008(1), §§ 42-101-42-111, 42-113(b); Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-5. - Light sources facing neighboring property. 
(a)  No artificial lighting shall shine directly upon any neighboring residential property or be so established that it shall shine directly upon any neighboring residential property or shall shine directly on or into any rooms, porches or patios of any neighboring structure or property as to be a nuisance. Nor shall any artificial lighting be maintained or operated from any structure or land in such a way as to be a nuisance to neighboring residential properties or as to impair vision though inordinate glare or to create a hazard to neighboring properties or as to interfere with the reasonable quiet enjoyment, use or comfort of the occupants of the neighboring residential properties. 
(b)  Exterior lighting facing neighboring residential property shall be hooded or shielded so that it does not produce an objectionable or inordinate glare on the neighboring residential property. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person responsible for such nuisance or annoying lighting as described in this section shall, upon a complaint having been made to the department of code enforcement, be issued a warning to abate said nuisance. For failure to comply within 14 days of receipt of said warning, said person shall be subject to a fine of $100.00. 
(Ord. of 4-14-2008(2); Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Secs. 26-6-26-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY RIGHTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-29. - Trespassing on exterior school property. 
    Trespassing on school property shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Code 1973, § 18-21.5; Code 1994, § 26-3; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-30. - Public notices, defacing or destroying. 
    A person shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws if he or she wantonly tears down, defaces or destroys any notice of any public meeting, auction or other sale or any other public notice lawfully posted. 
(Code 1973, § 18-16; Code 1994, § 26-10; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-31. - Street markers and signs, breaking or injuring. 
    A person shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws if he or she wantonly breaks down, injures, mars or destroys any monument or other memorial erected for the purpose of designating the boundaries of any street or highway in the city, or any tree, stake or other thing marked for that purpose, or breaks down, injures, mars or destroys any signboard erected upon any street or highway, or wantonly defaces or alters the inscription on any such board. 
(Code 1973, § 18-21; Code 1994, § 26-11; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Secs. 26-32-26-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRAFFITI[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 26-51-26-55, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1994, §§ 26-36-26-40; Ord. of 9-12-1994(2), § 18-100-18-103; Ord. of 2-10-2003. 

Sec. 26-51. - Declaration of policy. 
    The city and other urban areas throughout the country are experiencing unauthorized acts of vandalism by individuals that deface, disfigure or damage public and private property through the use of paint or other materials used to write names, initials, letters, symbols or other miscellaneous markings commonly known as "graffiti." This defacing, disfiguring or damaging of public and private property has created a form of visual pollution that has impacted the citizen's quality of life. The purpose of this article is to prevent same. 
(Ord. of 2-10-2003; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Sec. 26-52. - Graffiti restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person without the express consent of the property owner to paint, deface, disfigure or damage property, including, but not limited to, buildings, walls, fences, poles, containers, bridges, vehicles and all other structures and hard surfaces, through the use of paint or other indelible materials used to write names, initials, letters, symbols or other miscellaneous markings commonly known as "graffiti" and said person shall be charged in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Ord. of 2-10-2003; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 11-44-21.1. 
Sec. 26-53. - Enforcement and penalties for minors. 
    The agency charged with the enforcement of this division shall be the police department. This enforcement shall be done in conjunction and with referral and evaluation performed by the city's code enforcement director. Any minor violating the provisions of this division may be referred to the juvenile hearing board, who may subject the minor to a requirement of up to 50 hours of community service work. 
(Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Secs. 26-54-26-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROHIBITING SMOKING WITHIN PROXIMITY TO PUBLIC FACILITIES AND THE DELIVERY OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO MINORS 

Sec. 26-66. - [Intent.] 
    It is the intent of the City of Central Falls to create a tobacco free environment for schools, childcare centers: playgrounds and parks within the City of Central Falls. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2012 , § 1) 
Sec. 26-67. - Smoking prohibition. 
    Smoking and the use of tobacco products is prohibited in or on school grounds, child care facilities, playgrounds and parks within the City of Central Falls, to a distance including 25 feet of any entrance into or exit out of said buildings, including athletic fields, childcare facilities, playgrounds, parks and public events involving youth, families and seniors. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2012 , § 2) 
Sec. 26-68. - [Delivery of tobacco products to minors.] 
    Delivery of tobacco products to persons under the age of 18 is prohibited in accordance with R.I.G.L. 11-9-13 and 11-9-131. It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver any tobacco product or snuff to a person under the age of 18 years, nor shall any person under the age of 18 purchase any tobacco product snuff. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2012 , § 3) 
Sec. 26-69. - Signs to be erected. 
    The public works department is hereby directed to cause conspicuous signs giving notice that the above-referenced properties and facilities are tobacco free zones. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2012 , § 4) 
Sec. 26-70. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who violates this division shall be deemed to be creating a public nuisance, and violators shall be punishable to a fine of not less than $100.00 as well as subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-12 of the Revised Code of Ordinances of the City of Central Falls and or prosecuted in accordance with state statues where applicable. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, any violations of any provision of this division committed by any person under the age of 18 shall be referred to the municipal court. A first offense shall be punishable by a fine not less than $100.00, or 20 hours community service. Any subsequent offense shall require successful completion of a tobacco cessation program in addition to any fines imposed. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2012 , § 5) 
Secs. 26-71-26-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-84. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverage shall be consumed on city streets and sidewalks or within public parks and recreational facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume from and/or transport any open container containing alcoholic beverages on any public street, public sidewalk or public way. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12 with the first violation of this section being a fine of $50.00 and each and every offense thereafter being an increased fine of $50.00, up to a fine of no more than $500.00. A court of competent jurisdiction may refer a minor to the juvenile hearing board or, for any individual, may order up to 50 hours of community service instead of ordering a fine. 
(Code 1973, § 18-10; Code 1994, § 26-2; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, G.L. 1956, § 11-45-1. 
Sec. 26-85. - Sleeping in public. 
(a)  There shall be no sleeping in any public area of the city at night, including parks, streets and automobiles parked in any public area, except those places which provide sleeping accommodations for transient visitors. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12 with the first violation of this section being a fine of $50.00 and each and every offense thereafter being an increased fine of $50.00, up to a fine of no more than $500.00. A court of competent jurisdiction may refer a minor to the juvenile hearing board or, for any individual, may order up to 50 hours of community service instead of ordering a fine. 
(Code 1973, § 18-18; Code 1994, § 26-5; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Secs. 26-86-26-113. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Unreasonable noise levels, G.L. 1956, § 11-45.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-114. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for the first violation of this division shall be a fine of $100.00, a second violation of this division shall be a fine of $200.00 and a third and any subsequent violation shall be a fine of $500.00. Each fine shall be appealable to the municipal court. 
(Code 1994, § 18-71; Ord. of 8-30-1993, § 6; Ord. of 1-11-1999; Ord. of 1-10-2005(1); Ord. of 11-9-2015(1) ) 
Sec. 26-115. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to prohibit unreasonable, excessive and annoying noise levels from all sources subject to its police power. The noise being generated may originate from radios, CD players, DVD players, tape players, televisions and other audio-producing equipment. 
(Code 1994, § 18-67; Ord. of 8-30-1993, § 1; Ord. of 4-12-2004; Ord. of 11-9-2015(1) ) 
Sec. 26-116. - Enforcement. 
    The police chief or his designee shall train personnel in the proper use of sound level meters and criteria necessary for the enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 18-70; Ord. of 8-30-1993, § 5; Ord. of 11-9-2015 ) 
Sec. 26-117. - Violations of acceptable noise levels. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any equipment from which the sound created by this equipment is capable of penetrating a closed vehicle from 20 feet away from the locations at which the sound is being generated, or heard from 100 feet away by a person outside from which the sound is originating. This division shall include, but not be limited to, sound electronically generated by autos, trucks, scooters, motor homes, mobile homes, houses, apartment buildings, condominiums, commercial buildings, lawn maintenance equipment, or from any type of portable sound producing equipment that can be carried or placed outdoors which through its operation exceeds the provisions of this division. 
(b)  All state and municipal vehicles shall be exempt from the provisions of this division, nor any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity which holds a valid state or municipal entertainment license to sponsor a parade, carnival or other similar special event. 
(Code 1994, § 18-68; Ord. of 8-30-1993, § 2; Ord. of 4-12-2004; Ord. of 11-9-2015(1) ) 
Sec. 26-118. - Stereos, radios, musical instruments and other noisemaking devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any stereo, radio, musical instrument or other noisemaking device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner so as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of reasonable persons. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any stereo, radio, musical instrument or other noisemaking device for the producing or reproducing of sound within a motor vehicle in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of reasonable persons. 
(c)  Any noise level exceeding the ambient base level, as defined in section 26-117 anywhere along the street property, or property lines of any property, or if in a condominium or apartment house with any adjoining apartment, by more than five decibels shall be deemed to be prima facie a violation of the provisions of this division. In the case of a motor vehicle, the noise level must exceed the ambient base level by more than five decibels at least three feet from the motor vehicle. 
(Code 1994, § 18-69; Ord. of 8-30-1993, § 4; Ord. of 11-9-2015(1) ) 
Sec. 26-119. - Public education. 
    The police and fire departments shall conduct public education and post public signage to promote compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. of 11-9-2015(1) ) 
Secs. 26-120-26-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC SAFETY

    Permit requirements for weapons shall be in accordance with Chapter 44-11 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Code 1973, § 18-22; Code 1994, § 26-6; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
State Law reference- Possession, etc., of weapons, G.L. 1956, § 11-47-1 et seq.

(Code 1973, § 18-23; Code 1994, § 26-7; Ord. of 6-1-2005(1); Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1)

(Code 1973, § 18-12; Code 1994, § 26-9; Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 1) 
Chapter 28 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of parks, G.L. 1956, § 32-3-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC CONDUCT IN PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-19. - Playgrounds, parks and playing fields. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park means any city owned property designated for recreational purposes which shall include, but not be limited to Jenks Park, Pierce Park, the park at Hunt and Lewis Streets and any other parks created by the city. 
    Playground means any city owned property designated for recreational purposes which shall include, but not be limited to the following areas: Cowden Street, Illinois Street, Crossman Street, Sacred Heart Avenue, Garfield Street, tot playgrounds and any other playgrounds created by the city. 
    Playground, tot, means a playground designed and designated for children ten years old and under or any person who shall be supervising a child ten years old and under utilizing said tot playground. Hours of operation for tot playgrounds shall be from 8:30 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., which hours may be modified at the discretion of the chief of police to accommodate public safety issues. 
    Playing field means any city-owned property designated for athletic purposes which shall include, but not be limited to, the Francis Corrigan Sports Complex, Macomber Field, Tarlow Field and any other playing field created by the city. 
(b)  Written permission required. It is hereby declared illegal for any person to enter the playgrounds, parks, or playing fields in the city between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., or in the case of a tot playground between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 8:30 a.m. Any person or group of people wishing to use the playground, park, or playing field during the restricted hours may apply in writing for its use to the board of recreation or mayor and must be granted permission by the mayor or board of recreation. 
(c)  Penalty. The penalty for the first violation of this section shall be a fine of $50.00 and each and every offense thereafter shall include an increased fine of $50.00. 
(Code 1994, § 28-1; Ord. of 12-14-1998; Ord. of 8-25-2003) 
Sec. 28-20. - Prohibited uses; activities. 
(a)  Use by persons being detained or serving sentence. In order to provide for the immediate preservation of public peace, property, health or safety, the use of any public recreational facility, including, but not limited to, all baseball, softball, football, soccer, parks and any recreational fields or facilities by any person either being detained or serving a sentence for a convicted crime shall be prohibited. For the purpose of this section, the terms "person being detained" or "serving a sentence" shall include, but not be limited to, all those in custody of any and all private and public detention facilities, state or federal prisons within the United States. 
(b)  Acts by correctional or training officer while executing duty. It is prohibited for any correctional or training officer while executing his duty to enter, sit, stand, walk, surround, survey, guard or take post at or around, armed or unarmed, any park, ballfield, stadium, court or recreational facility or building owned by the city. 
(c)  Erecting bleachers, fences, etc., without approval. It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect, move or remove any buildings, stadiums, bleachers, fences or walls at any playground, ballfield, stadium or recreational field or facility owned by the city without first acquiring approval by a majority vote of the city council. 
(d)  Enforcement. The enforcement of this section shall lie with the police chief or the director of public safety. The fine for each offense shall be $500.00. 
(e)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The pursuit of an escapee. 
(2)  Training exercises for guards and training officers. 
(Code 1994, § 28-2; Ord. of 6-14-1994, §§ 1-5) 
Sec. 28-21. - Alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public parks or park means any land owned or leased by the city for the use of the public for any one or combination for the following uses, to wit: recreation, amusement, playground and field, swimming, trails, sports, bike paths, and any other area used by the public for relaxation or outdoor enjoyment. 
(b)  Alcohol consumption. Unless a permit for alcohol use, sale and consumption is granted by the city council or board of license commissioners, it shall be unlawful for any individual or group of individuals to bring into use, sell or possess alcoholic beverages anywhere within a public park. 
(c)  Penalties for violations. Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine not in excess of $1,000.00. 
(d)  Alcohol dispensing regulations. Pursuant to a permit for the use, sale and consumption of alcohol the city council or board of license commissioners may restrict the place, time and manner in which alcohol is to be dispensed. These restrictions may include the requirement that: 
(1)  A beer garden be constructed with fencing on all sides with one entrance/exit for the purpose of checking ages of patrons into the same; 
(2)  All alcohol shall be consumed within the beer garden; and 
(3)  The posting of a police officer at the entrance of the beer garden. 
(e)  Application procedure. All applicants for a permit to use, sell or consume alcohol in a public park shall comply with the following: 
(1)  File an application for a permit with the city clerk's office at least 45 days in advance of the date on which the permit is sought; 
(2)  Pay a $500.00 application fee which is set by the city council; 
(3)  Obtain written approval from the director of recreation; 
(4)  Obtain written instructions from the chief of police regarding the use of police details for the permit event; 
(5)  Provide proof of liability insurance which names the city as a loss payee; said insurance policy to be no less that $2,000,000.00; 
(6)  All servers must be tips, or stop certification (or equal); 
(7)  Applicant to sign indemnification agreement; 
(8)  Rescue vehicle to be posted on site. 
(Ord. of 7-28-2008) 
Sec. 28-22. - Smoking during sporting or other recreational events prohibited. 
(a)  Smoking tobacco in any form, during youth sporting events or any other recreational event sponsored for youth activity, shall not be permitted at any city owned property designated for athletic or recreational purposes which shall include, but not be limited to, the Francis Corrigan Sports Complex, Macomber Field, Tarlow Field and any other playing field or recreational facility created by the city. 
(b)  Any person who violates this section shall be deemed to be contributing to the maintenance of a public nuisance in a public place and shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00. 
(c)  This section does not prohibit smoking in designated areas during nonyouth sporting or other events held at these facilities. 
(Code 1994, § 28-3; Ord. of 12-10-2001) 
Sec. 28-23. - Establishment of permit for the use of recreational facilities; exceptions. 
(a)  The director of recreation is hereby authorized to issue a permit and charge a fee of $30.00 to any person, organization, or private club wishing to use any public recreational facility, including but not limited to, all baseball, softball, football, soccer, parks and any recreational fields or facilities owned by the city. 
(b)  The charge as described herein may be waived, in the discretion of the director of recreation, when the use of said facility is sponsored by a religious, charity or nonprofit group. 
(Code 1994, § 28-4; Ord. of 1-13-2003) 
Secs. 28-24-28-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - JENKS PARK, CITY PLAYGROUNDS, FRANCIS CORRIGAN SPORTS COMPLEX 

Sec. 28-50. - Vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall drive any vehicle into Jenks Park, city playgrounds or the Francis Corrigan Sports Complex without first obtaining permission from the chief of police. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12 with the first violation of this section being a fine of $50.00 and each and every offense thereafter being an increased fine of $50.00, up to a fine of no more than $500.00. A court of competent jurisdiction may refer a minor to the juvenile hearing board or, for any individual, may order up to 50 hours of community service instead of ordering a fine. 
(Code 1973, § 13-1; Code 1994, § 28-26; Ord. of 4-11-2005(1); Ord. of 9-14-2015(3) , § 3) 
Sec. 28-51. - Animals and fowl. 
    No person being the owner or having the charge or custody of any animal or fowl shall allow such animal or fowl to enter Jenks Park or to remain therein. This provision, however, shall not include guide dogs. 
(Code 1973, § 13-2; Code 1994, § 28-27) 
Sec. 28-52. - Bills and notices not to be posted. 
    No person shall post or otherwise affix any bill, notice or other paper upon any structure or thing within any part of Jenks Park, nor upon any of the gates or enclosures thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 13-3; Code 1994, § 28-28) 
Sec. 28-53. - Goods and circulars not to be sold or given away. 
    No person shall sell, expose for sale or give away any goods, wares or circulars in Jenks Park. 
(Code 1973, § 13-4; Code 1994, § 28-29) 
Sec. 28-54. - Lying upon or overturning seats prohibited. 
    No person shall lie upon or overturn any seat in Jenks Park. 
(Code 1973, § 13-5; Code 1994, § 28-30) 
Sec. 28-55. - Taking or injuring property; throwing stones.
