    No person shall take, pluck, injure, destroy, cut, mark or deface any flower, root, plant, shrub, tree, building, fence, monument or other property in Jenks Park. No person shall throw a stone or other missile in such park. 
(Code 1973, § 13-7; Code 1994, § 28-32) 
State Law reference- Vandalism, G.L. 1956, § 11-44-1. 
Chapter 30 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Refuse disposal, G.L. 1956, § 23-18.9-1 et seq.; littering, G.L. 1956, § 37-15-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Transportation. 
    No person shall transport over any street of the city any house offal, garbage, fruit, vegetable, wastepaper, cardboard cartons or other refuse whatsoever, or sand, gravel, crushed rock, coal or ashes, except in such a manner as will prevent the same from falling to and littering the streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 11-1; Code 1994, § 32-1) 
State Law reference- Prevention of load leakage, G.L. 1956, § 31-25-9; fastening and covering of load, G.L. 1956, § 31-25-9. 
Sec. 30-2. - Littering. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Excrement means manure, human or animal waste, or human or animal excrement. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food. 
    Household litter means any waste material generated or accumulated in or about a person's household, transported from such household, and then thrown, deposited or placed in any public receptacle. 
    Litter means items of garbage, refuse, or rubbish. 
    Public property means and includes all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleyways, highways, squares, spaces, grounds, parks, reservations, playgrounds, lands or buildings owned, controlled or maintained by the city. 
    Public waters means and includes all rivers, streams, lakes, ponds, and other bodies of water owned, controlled or maintained by the city and to which the public has the right to access. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned vehicles or parts thereof, solid markers, and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials. 
(b)  Prohibited. No person shall throw, deposit, place, cast, scatter, pile, leave or lay any litter in, about or upon any property or public waters in the city except in public receptacles provided for such purpose, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in public dumps; except, further, that no person shall deposit, place or leave any household litter, garbage or refuse in such public receptacles. 
(c)  Fine. The fine for this offense shall be $250.00. 
(Code 1973, §§ 11-2, 16-9-17; Code 1994, § 32-2; Ord. of 6-6-1990(1), § 11-2; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ) 
State Law reference- Littering, G.L. 1956, § 37-15-6. 
Sec. 30-3. - Accumulations on private property prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises within the city to permit any accumulation on premises owned or occupied by him of ashes, waste or refuse, other than in containers provided for in section 30-37. 
(b)  The penalty for the first violation of this section shall be a fine of $150.00 to the owner from which the nuisance will come. The second offense shall be a fine of up to $250.00 and each and every offense thereafter shall be a fine of up to $500.00. 
(Code 1973, § 11-3; Code 1994, § 32-3; Ord. of 6-6-1990(1), § 11-3; Ord. of 9-30-2002(2); Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ) 
Sec. 30-4. - Junk on premises of used car or auto parts dealer. 
(a)  No used car dealer or dealer in auto parts shall keep any junk or remains on his premises for a period of more than six days. 
(b)  All used tires and parts, trash or similar objects shall be stored in a fenced enclosure, located if possible in the rear half (or in the case of corner sites, rear quarter) of the site. All rubbish shall be stored in a clean and orderly manner and shall be removed from the site at least once a month. 
(Code 1973, § 11-4; Code 1994, § 32-4; Ord. of 4-11-2005(3)) 
Secs. 30-5-30-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RUBBISH COLLECTION 

Sec. 30-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combustible rubbish means all combustible material, including newspaper, magazines, cardboard boxes, cartons, wood (of proper size) rags, discarded clothing, leaves and grass clippings. 
    Commercial establishment means all establishments wherein business transactions or services are rendered to the public. Apartment houses with more than four dwelling units and mixed commercial and residential buildings are classified as "commercial establishments" for the purposes of this article. Excluded from this definition are properties that have qualified for a homestead exemption under section 34-45. 
    Dwelling unit means any room, or group of rooms, within a structure that is designed to be used by one family for living, sleeping, regular cooking (operating stove and refrigerator) and eating. 
    Garbage means all vegetable, animal, fish, fowl or fruit matter resulting from the use or storage of food for human consumption. 
    Noncombustible rubbish means all noncombustible waste, including fuel residue, tin or metal cans, bottles, household appliances and all other refuse not already defined as combustible or garbage, but excluding liquids. 
    Refuse includes garbage and combustible and noncombustible rubbish and which is used throughout this article to simplify the text. 
(Code 1994, § 32-26; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-28. - Violations and penalties; habitual offenders. 
    Violation of the provisions of this article or failure to comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this article or fails to comply with any of its requirements unless otherwise provided for in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined no less than $100.00 and, in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 32-38; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-29. - Complaints regarding violations. 
    Whenever a violation of this article occurs or is alleged to have occurred, any person may file a written complaint. Said complaint, stating fully the cause and basis thereof, shall be filed with the director of public works, or designee. The director shall properly record said complaint, investigate and take action as provided by this article. 
(Code 1994, § 32-37; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-30. - Director of public works and director of code enforcement to administer program. 
(a)  The director of public works shall have the charge, care and management of the personnel and equipment engaged in the administration of the program for collection of household refuse in the city. The director of public works and the director of code enforcement or their designee shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter which shall include the power to perform inspections, issue citations and prosecute violations. 
(b)  An enforcing officer may order the owner or occupant of any premises in the city to remove at his own expense any nuisance, refuse, solid waste, source of filth or filth found thereon within 24 hours after the service of notices as prescribed herein. 
(c)  The department of public works shall collect refuse from the residential structures and municipal buildings as set forth by this article. 
(Code 1994, § 32-27; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-31. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The director of public works, as part of his or her administrative powers, is empowered to establish refuse collection rules and regulations. 
(b)  In order for refuse to be collected on a weekly schedule by the city, property owners shall set aside said waste as described in section 30-36 except that the following shall be collected in the following manner in order to promote the safe and convenient handling of rubbish and to promote the orderly appearance of the city when rubbish is on the sidewalk awaiting collection: 
(1)  Tree limbs and wood must be four feet in length or less and tied in bundles. Wood must be free of all nails and screws. 
(2)  Rugs must be cut in half and four feet in length, tied and bundled. 
(3)  No sand, dirt, sod, rocks, demolition lumber, broken concrete, asphalt, plaster, brick or any other construction material will be collected. 
(4)  No automotive parts, tires, motor oil or other hazardous liquids will be collected. 
(5)  Refuse too large to place in containers as described in section 30-38 shall be required to be placed or arranged next to the container so that they may be picked up by the department. 
(6)  Frozen containers, containers containing hot/warm ashes, sod, and rocks will not be collected. 
(7)  Improperly disposed of rubbish/garbage and recycling not conforming to section 30-38 may be collected by the department and will be billed to the property owner in the amount of $100.00 per item. 
(Code 1994, § 32-28; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-32. - Frequency of collection, establishment of routes, days and times of collection; notices. 
(a)  Refuse shall be collected at least once a week from all commercial and residential structures in the city, or as many times as necessary in order to eliminate potential health hazards or as the director of public works or director of code enforcement may determine. 
(b)  The director of public works shall divide the city into districts for the collection of refuse combustibles and shall establish routes, days and times for the collection in each district. The director of public works shall provide reasonable notification of the day and time of collection when there is a change in the collections schedule for the householders in each district by any method which the director may consider advisable. 
(Code 1994, § 32-29; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-33. - Collection hours restricted. 
    Except for the removal of rubbish and recycling by the city, no one shall pick up or remove, not shall any person cause or allow to be picked up or removed, any refuse, rubbish, recycling or trash from any commercial or industrial establishments between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., if such establishment is located within 200 feet of a dwelling. 
(Code 1994, § 32-30; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-34. - Eligibility of household refuse collection by the department of public works. 
    The following uses or structures shall be eligible for household refuse collection by the city: 
(1)  Residential structures with five or fewer units. 
(2)  Public schools; 
(3)  Structures used for municipal offices or services; and 
(4)  Owner occupied residential structures with five units or more. In order to be eligible for this pickup a property owner must meet all the requirements of the homestead exemption as provided for in section 36-55 of this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 32-31; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 2-28-2005(1); Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 4-12-2010(1), § 32-31; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-35. - Collection of refuse at commercial establishments. 
(a)  Structures or multiple structures with more than five dwelling units on a lot, single or combined and structures containing mixed uses of commercial and residential are defined as "commercial establishments" and are not eligible for multiple refuse collection services. It is the responsibility of the owners of such structures, or their agents, to provide for the storage and collections of refuse in a manner fully consistent with this article. Such structures may employ a private collection services that utilizes either a commercial collection container, barrels with covers or plastic bags. 
(b)  All commercial trash and garbage containers (commonly known as dumpsters) shall be covered at all times, and the name, address and telephone number of said commercial contractor or company shall be prominently displayed on each container. 
(c)  Said commercial trash and garbage container shall be screened by fencing or shrubbery if visible from the street. 
(Code 1994, § 32-32; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 4-12-2010(2), § 32-32; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-36. - Placing for collection; removal of bulk and other special items. 
(a)  Property owners shall set rubbish in bags that have been properly tied and placed in 65 or 95 gallon containers provided by the city and bearing the city seal. Receptacles shall be placed on the curb without obstructing passage along the sidewalk. Rubbish shall be placed for collection on the day designated by the director of public works on the street on which the property is located in the time and manner provided for in section 30-40. 
(b)  The director of public works or his designee should be called for instructions regarding the pickup of large items and appliances. No resident of the city shall place any mattress, computers, televisions, furniture and all large metal items or appliances on the sidewalk for pickup without first having made an appointment with and paid a fee to the department of public works or designee. A fee equal to the cost for the removal and disposal of these items including metal items and appliances containing freon shall be charged. The director of public works shall notify the city council of any increases in fees. 
(Code 1994, § 32-33; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-11-2005(4); Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-37. - Garbage containers. 
    All garbage shall be deposited in 65 or 95 gallon containers provided by the city and bearing the city seal and shall at all times have a secure cover and/or the lid closed. The city will only supply the first garbage container and first recycling container to each property in the city and, thereafter, property owners are responsible for purchasing replacement containers. 
(Code 1994, § 32-34; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-38. - Authorized rubbish disposal. 
(a)  Rubbish and recycling shall be deposited in 65 or 95 gallon containers provided by the city and bearing the city seal and shall at all times have a secure cover and/or the lid closed. There shall not be overflowing rubbish or recycling nor trash bags on the ground nor any items improperly placed next to the garbage and recycling containers. 
(b)  Any violation of this section may be subject to the $100.00 fine outlined in section 30-31(b)(7). 
(Code 1994, § 32-35; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-39. - Failure to furnish and set out containers; notice to remove. 
(a)  The failure or neglect by any owner of any premises in the city to have a secured, closed lid on their garbage and recycling containers and/or to have sufficient containers for all rubbish and/or to set out such containers regularly for each collection or removal and/or to remove garbage and recycling containers from the curb the same day as collection shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(b)  Any violation of this article shall result in a notice of violation ticket in the amount of $150.00 per incident. The notice of violation ticket shall be in writing, signed by the enforcing officer and served by the enforcing officer, his or her designee, any sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable, police constable or the city sergeant or by leaving a copy of the order personally with or at the last and usual place of residence of the owner, or agent, if within the state or by affixing the notice of violation ticket to the rubbish or recycling container or item which is in violation. If the premises is occupied, or the residence of the owner or agent is unknown or without the state, the notice may be served by posting a certified copy of the notice on the premises, and by mailing a copy of the notice to the property owner at the address noted with the office of the tax assessor. Other methods of service as set forth in the municipal court rules of procedure may also be utilized by the city. 
(c)  If the owner or occupant fails to comply with the notice of violation ticket, the enforcing officer may cause the nuisance, source of filth, refuse, solid waste of filth to be removed; and all expenses incurred by the city shall be paid by the owner, occupant or other person who caused or permitted the refuse, solid waste or filth to be recovered in an action brought in the name of the city, including placing a lien on the property for all expenses and related costs incurred by the municipality which shall include an administrative fee of ten percent of the total costs of all expenses incurred by the municipality. 
(d)  Each day in excess of 24 hours that any person shall permit offending refuse or garbage to remain after receipt of such notice from the enforcing officer shall be deemed as a separate offense under this section. 
(Code 1994, § 32-36; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 4-18-2011(1), § 32-36(c); Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-40. - Time when containers may be set on curbs. 
    No rubbish containers shall be set out on curbs before 4:00 p.m. prior to the day set for collections, and such containers shall be removed the same day the collection has been made. 
(Code 1994, § 32-39; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-41. - Filling, covering and placing containers; negligence of owner of container. 
    The owner or occupant of any premises in the city shall have his or her 65 or 95 gallon containers provided by the city and bearing the city seal filled as compactly as naturally possible, shall have the containers securely covered to prevent scattering of the contents and shall place such containers on the curb to prevent cluttering of the sidewalk and damage to pedestrians and users of the sidewalks. Any damage caused by the negligence of the owner of any container shall be paid for by the owner, and the city shall not be held responsible therefor. 
(Code 1994, § 32-40; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-42. - Tampering with or removing containers. 
    No person shall in any manner remove, move, remove from or tamper with any rubbish or recycling container, whether full or empty. Violators of this section may be subject to a $250.00 fine from the director of public works and/or all applicable criminal penalties. 
(Code 1994, § 32-41; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Sec. 30-43. - Refusal to collect upon violation; removal by householder. 
    Wherever there has been failure to comply with the provisions of this article or with the rules and regulations established thereunder, the department of public works may refuse collection of any rubbish from the householder where such failure has occurred until such time as compliance and regulations established thereunder has occurred on a regular collection day. Any householder, the collection of whose rubbish has been refused as provided by this section, shall cause the rubbish to be removed forthwith at his own cost and expense. 
(Code 1994, § 32-42; Ord. of 10-18-2004; Ord. of 4-10-2006; Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Secs. 30-44-30-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REFUSE DISPOSAL FACILITIES 

Sec. 30-75. - Rules and regulations. 
    The director of public works shall have the power to make rules and regulations establishing minimum standards for permissible types of refuse disposal facilities. Such rules and regulations may not, however, be inconsistent with any rules, regulations, standards and criteria adopted by the state department of health regarding refuse disposal facilities. 
(Code 1973, § 11-18; Code 1994, § 32-61) 
Sec. 30-76. - Means of disposal to be approved. 
    Disposal of refuse shall be permitted only by sanitary landfills or incinerators or other means approved by the director of public works of the city and the state director of health. 
(Code 1973, § 11-19; Code 1994, § 32-62) 
Sec. 30-77. - Sanitary landfills. 
    Any person who maintains or operates a sanitary landfill as a public refuse disposal facility or permits the use of his land or land under his control for such a facility shall maintain such facility in conformance with any rules and regulations established by the director of public works of the city and the state department of health. 
(Code 1973, § 11-20; Code 1994, § 32-63) 
Sec. 30-78. - Incinerators. 
(a)  Construction. Any person who constructs or causes to be constructed any incinerator which is to be used as a public refuse disposal facility shall construct such facility according to the standards established by the director of public works of the city and the state department of health. 
(b)  Maintenance and operation. Any person who maintains or operates an incinerator as a public refuse disposal facility shall maintain such facility in conformance with standards established by the director of public works of the city and the state department of health. 
(Code 1973, §§ 11-21, 11-22; Code 1994, § 32-64) 
Sec. 30-79. - Identification of commercial trash containers. 
(a)  The name, address and telephone number shall be displayed prominently on all commercial trash and garbage containers (dumpsters). 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of $100.00 for the first offense and $100.00 for each subsequent violation. 
(Code 1994, § 32-65; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 11-24; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ) 
Sec. 30-80. - Commercial trash containers to be covered. 
(a)  All commercial trash containers must be covered. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of $50.00 for the first offense and $100.00 for each subsequent violation. 
(Code 1994, § 32-66; Ord. of 10-15-1985, § 11-25) 
Sec. 30-81. - Commercial collection, duty of owner. 
(a)  Every owner of a dwelling using commercial rubbish removal (dumpsters) shall provide for proper collection and removal of the contents thereof. 
(b)  Every owner of a commercial rubbish receptacle (dumpster) shall be responsible for the proper collection and removal of the contents of such containers. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of $100.00 for the first violation and by a fine of $100.00 for each subsequent violation. 
(Code 1994, § 32-67; Ord. of 10-15-1985, §§ 11-26, 11-27; Ord. of 12-19-2011(6) ) 
Secs. 30-82-30-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Waste recycling, G.L. 1956, § 23-18.8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 30-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Arrangements means the process by which the city plans for and carries out the separation, weighing, collection, hauling and disposal of solid waste generated within the city. 
    Hazardous waste means any waste as defined in G.L. 1956, § 23-19.1-4, or in regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
    Household hazardous waste means hazardous municipal solid waste. 
    Local recycling program means a recycling program for municipal solid waste as set forth in a local recycling plan approved by the state pursuant to the municipal recycling regulations, as amended. 
    Mixed recyclables are defined by guidelines promulgated by the director of public works and/or Rhode Island Resource Recovery. 
    Municipal solid waste means solid waste generated by the residents of the city in the course of their daily living, the disposal of which the city council has undertaken in the discharge of its duties to protect the health of the municipality. The term "municipal solid waste" does not include solid waste generated by residents of the city in the course of their employment or that generated by any manufacturing or commercial enterprise. 
    Recyclable materials are all materials as established by Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines. The materials to be included may change from time to time depending upon new technologies, economic conditions, waste stream characteristics, environmental effects or mutual agreement between the state and municipalities. 
    Resident means anyone residing in the city for any period of time who generated solid waste for which the city accepts responsibility for disposal. 
    Solid waste means garbage, refuse and other discarded solid materials generated by residential, institutional, commercial, industrial and agricultural sources but not including solids or dissolved material in domestic sewage or sewage sludge, nor hazardous waste as defined in the hazardous waste management act, G.L. 1956, § 23-19.1-1 et seq. 
    Source separation means the removal by the generator of recyclable materials, including mixed recyclables from all other solid waste generated by the household along with the removal of solid waste from mixed recyclables generated by the household, and conveyance of the recyclables to the curbside or other designated location by the municipality or its agents. 
    White goods means major kitchen or laundry appliances, including, but not limited to, stoves, washers, refrigerators and dryers. Nothing in this definition shall waive compliance with the rules and regulations for generation, transportation, storage and disposal of hazardous waste. 
(Code 1994, § 32-92; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § IB; Ord. of 3-18-1998(2); Ord. of 5-11-2015 , § 1) 
Sec. 30-107. - Implementation. 
    A mandatory recycling program is hereby implemented in the city pursuant to G.L. 1956, ch. 23-18.8 (G.L. 1956, § 23-18.8-1 et seq.) and G.L. 1956, ch. 23-18.9 (G.L. 1956, § 23-18.9-1 et seq.), and the Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines, as amended, and state department of environmental management municipal recycling regulations, as amended. 
(Code 1994, § 32-91; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § IA; Ord. of 5-11-2015 , § 1) 
Sec. 30-108. - Compliance required. 
    All residents, taxpayers and others doing business in the city shall separate recyclables from the non-recyclable portion of their solid waste and prepare them for recycling according to directions published by the city. Rubbish and recycling shall be deposited in 65 or 95-gallon containers provided by the city and bearing the city seal and shall at all times have a secure cover and/or the lid closed. 
(Code 1994, § 32-93; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § ID; Ord. of 5-11-2015 , § 1) 
Sec. 30-109. - Mandatory recycling requirements. 
(a)  Source separation for collection . In accordance with state law and/or department of environmental management regulations and/or Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines, mandatory recycling will be accomplished by source separation with curbside collection. 
(1)  Curbside collection . The city shall provide for collection of mixed recyclables once per week from residents in dwellings serviced by the existing curbside collection contract. The collection of mixed recyclables shall be accomplished on the same day as the collection of non-recyclable materials. This day shall be designated by the director of public works. 
(2)  Special recycling containers . Every property owner and/or tenant shall be provided with a 65 or 95-gallon container provided by the city and bearing the city seal wherein recyclables will be placed at curbside for collection as prescribed by the department of public works. Recyclable materials shall be prepared according to directions published by the director of public works and/or Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines. 
(3)  Method of container distribution . Containers shall be distributed in accordance with department of public works regulations. The initial container will be provided to each property owner and/or tenant free of charge. If a container must be replaced, the property owner and/or tenant shall be charged the currently required replacement fee. 
(4)  Materials requiring special disposal . Oil paint, computers and computer equipment and any other material requiring special disposal shall be disposed of pursuant to guidelines promulgated by the director of public works and/or Rhode Island Resource Recovery. 
(b)  Notice of violation; penalties for noncompliance . 
(1)  Any violation for failure to separate recyclable and non-recyclable materials in accordance with Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines or for leaving recyclables prepared in a manner inconsistent with department of public works regulations or Rhode Island Resource Recovery guidelines shall result in a notice of violation ticket in the amount of $250.00 per incident, with notice and an opportunity to be heard and appealed in the municipal court. The notice shall advise the resident of his or her duties by law. A copy of such notice shall be kept by the director of public works. 
(2)  After the first notice of violation ticket has been issued, each additional notice of violation ticket within a one year period shall be in the amount of $500.00 and shall be accompanied with a summons to appear in municipal court for an opportunity to appeal and be heard. 
(3)  The notice of violation ticket shall be in writing, signed by the enforcing officer and served by the enforcing officer, his or her designee, any sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable, police constable or the city sergeant or by leaving a copy of the order personally with or at the last and usual place of residence of the owner, or agent, if within the state or by affixing the notice of violation ticket to the recycling container in violation. If the premises is occupied, or the residence of the owner or agent is unknown or without the state, the notice may be served by posting a certified copy of the notice on the premises, and by mailing a copy of the notice to the property owner at the address noted with the office of the tax assessor. Other methods of service as set forth in the municipal court rules of procedure may also be utilized by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 32-94; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § IC; Ord. of 2-8-1999; Ord. of 9-13-2004; Ord. of 5-11-2015 , § 1) 
Sec. 30-110. - Ownership of recyclables. 
(a)  Once municipal solid waste has been deposited at curbside for collection by the department of public works, such solid waste becomes the property of the city. No resident, taxpayer or other person engaged in the business of separation, recovery, collection, removal, storage or disposition of solid waste shall pick up or procure any recyclable materials within the city for personal gain except as specifically authorized by the director of public works. 
(b)  The director of public works may issue permits to charitable organizations to collect recyclable materials on the condition that a report is filed by such organization detailing the weights of each material collected in compliance with state department of environmental management reporting requirements and provided that the director of public works determines that such collection does not conflict with the city's recycling implementation program. 
(Code 1994, § 32-95; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § II) 
Sec. 30-111. - Commercial recycling. 
    Business firms shall be subject to state and federal recycling regulations. 
(Code 1994, § 32-96; Ord. of 9-11-1989, § ID) 
Chapter 32 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Maintenance of town highways, G.L. 1956, § 24-5-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Laying out sidewalks on petition of abutting landowners. 
(a)  The city council is hereby authorized in its discretion, upon the petition of abutters on public highways, to make concrete, cement or granolothic sidewalks, according to the choice of such abutters on such public highways, such abutters so petitioning to pay one-half of the cost of such work and the city the other half. Such work, when ordered by the city council, shall be done under the direction of the department of public works. 
(b)  The city council may make rules as to the payment of the cost of work done under this chapter by the abutters, or it may authorize the department of public works to make rules as to the payment of such cost. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23-1, 23-2; Code 1994, § 34-1) 
State Law reference- Division of cost between city and landowners, G.L. 1956, § 24-7-3. 
Sec. 32-2. - Sale of goods or merchandise on streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall sell, display, display for sale or offer for sale or suffer to be sold any goods, wares or merchandise of any type, nature or description whatsoever, however named, called or described, in or from any open-air stand or in any open-air area or on or from any stand adjacent to or near any building or from any place other than a building, or shall make sales on any sidewalk in the city, unless and until he shall have obtained a license therefor from the city council. Such person shall first make application, giving the size, location, nature and purpose of the stands and the area or place to be used. The council may grant such license upon such terms and conditions as in their discretion are necessary and essential. The granting of such licenses is not mandatory, since the welfare of the public is of primary consideration. The license fee therefor shall be established from time to time for each period of one year, such licenses to be prorated from June 1 in each year. 
(Code 1973, § 23-3; Code 1994, § 34-2) 
Sec. 32-3. - Use of streets for recreational purposes. 
(a)  Children's baths and showers from hydrants. The board of recreation is hereby authorized and empowered to use certain streets which are not main arteries of travel for the purpose of furnishing children with an opportunity to use and enjoy baths and showers from and at hydrants during the period set aside by the board of recreation for recreational activities. 
(b)  Block parties. The board of recreation is authorized and empowered to set off certain streets for the purpose of block parties. 
(c)  Exclusion of vehicular traffic. For either purpose mentioned in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the board of recreation is authorized and empowered to rope off so much of the streets as shall be deemed necessary to the exclusion of all vehicular traffic, which vehicular traffic shall include bicycles, motor vehicles and other type vehicles. 
(d)  Supervision of streets so used. Each street used for the purposes mentioned in this section shall be under the supervision of someone duly authorized by the board of recreation. 
(e)  Trespassing in recreational area. No person shall trespass into the restricted area provided for in subsection (c) of this section without the consent or authority of the board of recreation or its designated agent with any vehicle described in this section, nor shall any person trespass into such area without such permission. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23-10-23-14; Code 1994, § 34-4) 
Sec. 32-4. - Vehicles on sidewalks. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven, backed, moved or allowed to stand on any sidewalk, except for the purpose of crossing the sidewalk when necessary; and in such case, such vehicle shall use the shortest way from the street to the abutting estate. 
(b)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be $15.00. 
(Code 1973, § 23-17; Code 1994, § 34-6) 
Sec. 32-5. - Depositing cans, dirt and other substances on streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited in or upon any street, highway, sidewalk or public place any tin pans or cans, dirt, sweepings, coal, dust, soot, ashes, cinders, shavings, hair, shreds, manure, oyster, clam or lobster shells, or any animal or vegetable matter or substance whatsoever. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as forbidding the placing of sand or other substances on sidewalks encumbered by ice, or the removing of snow from sidewalks at any time as provided in sections 32-8 and 32-9. 
(Code 1973, § 23-18; Code 1994, § 34-7) 
State Law reference- Littering, G.L. 1956, § 37-15-6. 
Sec. 32-6. - Hoisting or lowering merchandise over streets. 
    No merchandise shall be hoisted or lowered into or out of any building over any street, highway or public place in any manner so as to endanger people lawfully using such street, highway or public place. 
(Code 1973, § 23-24; Code 1994, § 34-8) 
Sec. 32-7. - Obstructing sidewalks. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall stand on any footwalk, sidewalk, doorstep or in any doorway or shall ride, drive, fasten or leave any horse or other animal or any carriage, team or any other vehicle on any such footwalk, sidewalk, doorstep or doorway within the city to the obstruction, hindrance, delay, disturbance or annoyance of passersby or of persons residing or doing business in the vicinity thereof. 
(b)  By loading or unloading merchandise. On streets not otherwise restricted, merchandise may be transferred from or to trucks or other vehicles over the sidewalks by the use of skids and planks when necessary; provided, that the sidewalk is not unreasonably obstructed, and then only for such reasonable time as is necessary. If the sidewalk and travel thereon is obstructed by such skids or planks for more than ten minutes at a time, any police officer may order such skids or planks removed. If not removed, he may himself remove them or cause them to be removed. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23-25, 23-26; Code 1994, § 34-9) 
Sec. 32-8. - Removal of snow from sidewalks and prohibition on disposal of snow on streets. 
(a)  The owner, occupant or other person having the care of any building or lot of land bordering on any street, highway, square or public place where there is a sidewalk supported by curbing shall, within the first four hours of daylight after the ceasing to fall of any snow, cause the snow to be removed from the sidewalk adjoining such building or lot of land. In case of neglect so to do, the person chargeable with this duty shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 for each and every hour after the expiration of such four hours that the snow shall remain on the sidewalk. The provisions of this section shall also apply to the falling of snow from any building. 
(b)  No owner, lessee or occupant of any premises, or any person cleaning or removing snow there from, shall deposit, permit or cause to be deposited any snow from said premises upon any street or public place except with the permission of the director of public works. 
    Any person found guilty of violating this subsection shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00. Enforcement shall be the responsibility of the city police department and/or an inspector or supervisor of the city public works department. The imposition of such fine and other charges may be appealed to municipal court within ten days of the issuance of a written citation. 
(Code 1973, § 23-27; Code 1994, § 34-10; Ord. of 4-18-2011(2)) 
Sec. 32-9. - Removal of ice from sidewalks. 
    Whenever any sidewalk or any part thereof adjoining any building or lot of land on any street, highway, square or public place where such sidewalks are supported by curbing shall be encumbered by ice, it shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or other person having the care of such building or lot to cause the sidewalk to be made safe and convenient by removing the ice therefrom or by covering such ice with sand or some other suitable substance. In case such owner, occupant or other responsible person shall neglect so to do for the space of three hours during the daytime, he shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 and in a like manner for every day thereafter that the sidewalk shall continue to be so encumbered. 
(Code 1973, § 23-28; Code 1994, § 34-11) 
Sec. 32-10. - Removal of injurious substances from streets and sidewalks. 
    Whenever, from accident or casualty, any liquid or other substance which may injure by contact therewith any man or beast, or any glass or other solid substance which may render travel unsafe to man or beast or vehicles upon the highway shall be thrown or deposited in any street or sidewalk, the person in whose charge and control such liquid or substance was at the time of such accident shall, as soon as reasonably may be, by removal of such liquid or substance or otherwise, restore the street or sidewalk to a clean condition, safe and convenient for travel. 
(Code 1973, § 23-29; Code 1994, § 34-12) 
Sec. 32-11. - Wetting down or placing water on streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. of any day, wet down the sidewalks of or use water upon the outside of any structure abutting upon or near to any public street in the city in any manner that may cause annoyance or inconvenience to anyone having the right to use the street or sidewalk during the time aforesaid, and no person shall wet down any such sidewalk or use water in any manner that may cause such water to come upon such sidewalk or street at any time when such water may be likely to freeze upon such sidewalk or street. 
(Code 1973, § 23-30; Code 1994, § 34-13) 
Sec. 32-12. - Tree ordinance. 
(a)  Purpose . This section shall establish the Central Falls Tree Advisory Board, which shall be responsible for a devising and educating on issues pertaining to trees and wooded plants in the City of Central Falls, and to maintain the status of Tree City USA. 
(b)  Definitions . 
(1)  Street trees . Trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(2)  Park trees . Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the City, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
(c)  Board established . There is established for the City of Central Falls an advisory board to be known as the Central Falls Tree Advisory Board. 
(d)  Membership and compensation . The Central Falls Tree Advisory Board shall consist of three members who live or work in the Central Falls area and whom the mayor, with the approval of the city council, shall appoint. The members shall serve without compensation for services performed. 
(e)  Appointments/terms of office. The term of the persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three years. In the event a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. The first board shall serve as follows: One member shall serve for one year, one member shall serve for two years, and one member shall serve for three years. The mayor, for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or irreconcilable conflict may remove members. 
(f)  Meetings . The board shall meet quarterly. The board shall determine meeting dates and times. Special meetings may be held as often as the Board deems necessary or as directed by the mayor or city council. For purposes of conducting the board's business, exercising its powers and for all other purposes, a quorum of the board shall consist of two or more members. Any action taken by a majority of those present, when those present constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting of the board, shall be deemed and taken as the action and decision of the board. The board shall elect such officers, as it deems necessary to conduct business. The board shall adopt such rules of procedure, as it deems necessary. The board shall keep written minutes of all meetings held and all business transacted. All records of the Board shall be open to public inspection, except those that may be exempt from public disclosure under state law. 
(g)  Duties of the advisory board . The Board shall acquire authorization form the director of public works prior to under taking any project. The duties of the tree board shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Promote the responsible planting of trees on public and private property. 
(2)  Promoting public education about trees. 
(3)  Promoting proper tree maintenance. 
(4)  Advocating trees within the City of Central Falls. 
(5)  Providing for aesthetics within the City of Central Falls through the formulation and implementation of tree programs. 
(6)  Developing programs and projects while working with other community groups to enhance the city's beautification. 
(7)  Developing innovative and joint funding for tree projects from a variety of sources. 
(8)  Providing the mayor and city council with a yearly report regarding tree board activities. 
(9)  Develop, maintain and provide a tree standard manual for proper tree planting, maintenance and care of trees and wooded plants, by development of landscaping and/or tree ordinances within the city, as well as reviewing project plans for compliance with said ordinances as requested by city staff. 
(h)  Utilities . No street trees may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(i)  Public tree care . The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners. 
(j)  Tree topping . It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the board. 
(k)  Pruning, corner clearance . Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(l)  Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The board will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the owner's property tax notice or to file a lien against the property. 
(m)  Removal of stumps. All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(n)  Authorized . The tree warden is hereby authorized on petition of abutters on public sidewalks and with approval of the tree advisory board to issue a permit to plant street trees of a species approved by the tree warden on the sidewalks and in such places as approved by the director of public works and the tree advisory board. 
(o)  Cost . The director of public works is authorized to certify one-half of the cost of planting trees under this section to the director of finance, who is hereby authorized to pay such cost from the public works budget. 
(p)  Penalty and appeal. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine by the tree advisory board not to exceed $500.00 per violation. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the tree advisory board to the board of appeals who may hear the matter and render a final decision. 
(Code 1973, § 23-30.5; Code 1994, § 34-15; Ord. of 3-23-2015(2)) 
Sec. 32-13. - Repairing and/or servicing of motor vehicles on public property. 
(a)  No person shall, within the city, repair and/or service any motor vehicle on public streets, within public parks, within public playgrounds, within public parking lots or on other public property except in an emergency. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of this section shall be $50.00 for the first offense and $100.00 for each subsequent offense. 
(Code 1973, § 23-30.7; Code 1994, § 34-16) 
Sec. 32-14. - Liability for damage from defective roads; recovery of amount of damage. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 24-5-13, if any person shall incur damage to his motor vehicle by reason of a pothole on any city highway, causeway, street, lane or bridge, which damage would have not occurred without the existence of the pothole, he may recover from the city the amount of damages sustained up to and not more than the sum of $300.00; provided, however, that the municipality had reasonable notice of the pothole, or may have had notice thereof by the exercise of proper care and diligence on its part, and a reasonable opportunity to repair the pothole. 
(b)  All claims shall be made within a period of seven days from the date on which the damage was sustained by filing a written report in a manner prescribed by the city. In no instance, however, shall any claim for damage so caused to a motor vehicle registered in a foreign state be considered unless that state has a similar statute affording similar protections to persons owning motor vehicles registered in this state. 
(Code 1994, § 34-17; Ord. of 4-11-2005(6)) 
Secs. 32-15-32-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1, amended article II in its entirety to read as herein set out. In addition to new provisions being added, former provisions were kept and renumbered. The historical notation remains with the renumbered provisions. For a more detailed description of changes to this article see the code comparative table. 

Sec. 32-32. - Purpose and scope. 
    The city recognizes the importance of new installations, maintenance and upgrading of utility service to ensure the public welfare. The purpose of this article is to ensure the long-term integrity of city infrastructure, to promote cooperation between the city and persons with an interest in excavating city streets and to ensure any excavation of a public right away is restored to the same condition or better than it was found before the excavation. 
(Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-33. - Definitions. 
    The terms defined below shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this chapter except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Chief of police shall refer to the chief of police of the central falls police department. 
(2)  City shall refer to the City of Central Falls. 
(3)  Director shall refer to the director of the department of public works for the city. 
(4)  DPW shall refer to the department of public works for the city. 
(5)  Emergency shall refer to a situation that presents an immediate and serious risk of injury, loss of life, or damage to property or public welfare. 
(6)  Emergency repair work shall refer to any excavation work which is in response to or necessitated by an emergency. 
(7)  Excavation work shall refer to, but is not limited to, any compacting, construction, cutting, digging, excavation, occupation, use, repair, or other disturbance in or under a street, road, sidewalk, or other public right-of-way. 
(8)  Permanent patch shall refer to final repair of excavation work to be performed in accordance with these standards and intended to permanently return the opened portion of the roadway to as good a condition as or better than it was prior to the performance of the excavation work. 
(9)  Permit shall refer to a permit granted by the city to a person for permission to do street opening work in a public way. 
(10)  Person or persons shall refer, but not limited to, any contractor, corporation, entity, firm, or utility. For the purpose of this article, "person" shall also refer to any contractors, subcontractors, or agents of the persons. 
(11)  Protected street shall refer to any street, road, right-of-way, or sidewalk that was been paved by the city within the last five years. 
(12)  Temporary patch shall refer to the interim application of bituminous concrete with the anticipation of a permanent patch. 
(13)  Utility shall refer to any and all persons or entities engaged in the transmission and distribution of electrical energy, natural gas, water, and telephonic, visual and other communication systems. For the purpose of this article, "utility" shall also refer to any contractors, subcontractors, or agents of the utility. 
(Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-34. - Permit required. 
    Prior to the start of excavation work, a permit shall be issued by the DPW. Permits shall be issued upon payment of $75.00 to the DPW. Such permits shall specify the time, place, size, and nature of the project. Applicants seeking permits must also list any contractors, subcontractors, or agents, who will be performing the proposed work. 
(1)  The city reserves the right to request from the applicant a surety performance bond relative to the extent and scope of the proposed excavation work being contemplated within the city's right-of-way areas. 
(2)  A person or a utility applying for a permit shall provide a certificate of general liability insurance or appropriate evidence of self-insurance of not less than $500,000.00 naming the city as an additional insured. 
(3)  Any material misrepresentation from the plans approved by the DPW may result in the cancellation of said permit. If excavation work has already begun, the permittee shall be responsible for any work needed to restore the area to the same condition or better before any excavation work. 
(4)  The city reserves the right to revoke any permit if the director deems that the permittee has exceeded the time, place, size, or nature of the project that was originally approved in the permitting process. 
(5)  A copy of each permit issued will be given to the chief of police who is hereby authorized to require the person receiving the permit to maintain, at the expense of such person, as many police officers on special duty or detail as the chief of police may determine necessary to protect the safety and general welfare of the public and to preserve the free circulation of traffic and to require the person receiving the permit to enclose the opening, occupied or used area with a rail, fence or other guard if determined necessary by the chief of police, subject to the payment requirements of section 22-125. 
(6)  Any person conducting work subject to this article is responsible for ensuring compliance, by itself and its contractors, with these standards. Any work, in relation to this article, may be inspected by the city to ensure compliance with these standards. In the event of noncompliance, the person shall, at their own expense, correct such failures. 
(7)  A copy of the permit must be on the job site at all times for inspection. Repeated failures to have the permit available may result in the suspension of the permit. This provision is not applicable during emergency repair work. 
(8)  In the event that any person or utility engages in any of the activities described in this article without obtaining the required permit, that person or utility shall be subject to a fine of $500.00 per violation per day. 
(Code 1973, § 23-19; Code 1994, § 34-36; Ord. of 11-14-1994; Ord. of 3-21-2011; Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-35. - Street pavement plan. 
(a)  The city shall develop and maintain a comprehensive program for categorizing the condition of city streets and a projected schedule for street repairs and repaving hereinafter "the plan." The plan will be posted on the city's website and shall be provided to each utility operating in the city. The plan will be published on the first of March of each year. 
(b)  The plan will contain a good-faith listing that contains a ranking of proposed streets and sidewalks that are a priority for repaving, subject to available funding, and will also contain a listing of roads considered for repaving during the ensuing 24 months. 
(c)  The purpose of the report is to identify which streets, roads, rights-of-way, or sidewalks that will be paved by the city and promote communication and cooperation between the city, utilities, persons. 
(d)  Any utility operating in the city shall work with the city to minimize the impact of utility roadwork and specifically to reduce the incidence of non-emergency utility excavation in newly-paved streets. 
(e)  Any utility anticipating major work in any of the streets which are scheduled for repaving in the ensuring 18 months shall notify the city of the utility's plan by March 1 of each year. 
(Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-36. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  Any person performing excavation work shall restore the excavation work location to the same condition or better. The city reserves to right to evaluate the restored condition of the excavation work and if the condition is not satisfactory to the DPW, the city may order the person who conducted the excavation work to cure any issues. 
(b)  Any existing plaque, emblem, marker or symbol embedded within said street or sidewalk before such excavation work was effectuated shall be replaced in the same location and condition upon completion of such excavation work. 
(c)  The permanent patching of bituminous concrete base and top shall be laid and rolled in two courses. The binder (base course) shall be two and one-half inches in depth and the top course shall be one and one-half inches in depth. The minimum total thickness of both courses, measured after rolling, shall be four inches. The base course of the permanent pavement shall be placed and carefully raked to a minimum surface and thoroughly rolled to the required thickness. Before placing the base course of the permanent pavement, the edge of the original bituminous surface shall receive an application of approved asphalt emulsion so that the new pavement material may be properly bonded to the old. The top course of the permanent pavement shall be placed to the grade that matches the existing bituminous surface after rolling. The permanent paving shall not overlap the existing pavement and will not have to be applied with a mechanical spreader unless otherwise directed. The permittee shall furnish, place, grade and compact bituminous concrete pavement of class I type I-1 as shown and specified in the latest state standard construction specifications for road and bridge. The director shall evaluate each permit application and determine if the patch requires infrared treatment. 
(d)  Temporary patching shall be in accordance with the standard specifications of the state department of public works and is to be a minimum of two-inch compacted thickness. 
(e)  For a period of five years, any excavation work done on a protected street or a paved location that was previously listed on the plan, following the permanent paving of any street, road, right-of-way, or sidewalk, any excavation work will require pavement restoration from curb to curb for the entire length of city block wherein the excavation is located. 
(Code 1973, § 23-20; Code 1994, § 34-37; Ord. of 1-12-2009; Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-37. - Lighting. 
    The person receiving the permit shall place and maintain from the beginning of twilight, through the whole of every night, over or near the place so occupied, opened, obstructed or used, and over or near any dirt, gravel or other material placed in or near such place, lights sufficient to protect travelers from injury; shall place and maintain a safe and convenient way satisfactory to the chief of police, for the use of foot travelers and for vehicles around or over such place. 
(Code 1973, § 23-21; Code 1994, § 34-38; Ord. of 11-14-1994; Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-38. - Failure to restore satisfactorily; work done by city; cost. 
    In case any street or sidewalk is not left in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works under the provisions of section 32-33, he or she shall cause the work to be properly done, and the expense thereof shall be charged to and paid by the person conducting excavation work. 
(Code 1973, § 23-22; Code 1994, § 34-39; Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-39. - Fine. 
    Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this article may be prohibited from undertaking any activity involving further excavation work for a period deemed reasonable by the director of public works. Such failure of compliance shall be punishable by a fine of $500.00 for each and every violation per day. Any fine issued in accordance to this article shall be subject to appeal in municipal court within 30 days. 
(Code 1994, § 34-40; Ord. of 11-14-1994; Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Sec. 32-40. - Public emergency. 
    In the case of a public emergency occurring during a time when a permit is not easily available, and the emergency requires the emergency repair work, the person shall not be required to obtain a permit from the DPW. Such person, however, shall notify the chief of police where the work will be located and the cause for the emergency repair work. Such person shall only begin work once they receive written authorization from the chief of police. Any person operating under a public emergency authorization shall still comply with the provisions of this article, and shall apply for a permit with the DPW within 30 days thereafter or be subject to the fines and penalties provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-18-2017(2) , § 1) 
Secs. 32-41-32-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAY OPENINGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-61. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall perform any work in violation of any specifications of plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order, as affirmed or modified by the board of appeals, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall severally, for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-13; Code 1994, § 34-63) 
Sec. 32-62. - Administration. 
(a)  Powers of director of public works. The director of public works shall execute the provisions of this article, and the ordinances in amendment hereof, except as otherwise provided. He shall have the power to act on any question relative to the administration and enforcement of this article, including the issuance and revocation of permits, the collection of fees, the inspection of the work and materials, the holding of bonds, and the issuance of notices and orders necessary to the proper implementation of this article. 
(b)  Maintenance of records. The director shall maintain a record of all permits issued, all fees levied and all bonds posted. He shall keep a record of all violations of law, and shall report all violations to the city solicitor. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-1; Code 1994, § 34-61) 
Sec. 32-63. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by any officer, department, board, commission, or agency of the city may take an appeal to the board of appeals, from any decision of the director of public works. Any appeal may be taken within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed by filing with the director, and with the board of appeals, a notice of appeal, specifying the grounds thereof. The director shall forthwith transmit to the board of appeals all the papers upon which the action appealed was taken. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-12; Code 1994, § 34-62) 
Secs. 32-64-32-84. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 32-85. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or alter any curb cut or driveway opening without first having obtained a permit from the director of public works, and on state controlled highways, a permit must be obtained from the state department of public roads and bridges, and work must conform to state and city standards. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-2(a); Code 1994, § 34-76) 
Sec. 32-86. - Application. 
    Before a permit for a curb cut or driveway is issued, the owner shall submit an application in such a manner and on such a form as prescribed by the director of public works. Every application shall be accompanied by a dimensional plan drawn to scale, showing the location of the proposed curb cut, or driveway opening; the location of existing curb cuts, or driveway openings on the same lot; the distance from the proposed curb cut, or driveway opening to lot lines; the location of street intersections, when applicable, and the locations of existing or proposed buildings, curbs, sidewalks, trees, poles, public utilities, or other objects which might affect the work. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-2(b); Code 1994, § 34-77) 
Sec. 32-87. - Action on application. 
    The director shall examine all applications for permits, and shall refer all such applications, if deemed necessary, to the city traffic division, and if, in the opinion of the director of public works, the application and the plans attached thereto are in conformance with the provisions of this division, the director shall issue a permit for the work to be performed. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-2(c); Code 1994, § 34-78) 
Sec. 32-88. - Compliance. 
    All work shall be done in compliance with the permit issued for said work and all work must be completed within 60 days from issuance of permit. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-2(d); Code 1994, § 34-79) 
Sec. 32-89. - Revocation. 
    The director of public works shall revoke any permit as follows: 
(1)  If any reason is found to exist that would have been cause to deny such permit. 
(2)  Whenever there has been a false statement as to material fact in the application upon which the permit was issued. 
(3)  For any violation of any provision of this division, on the part of the permittee, or his agent or employee, in doing any act or work authorized to be done by such permit. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-2(e); Code 1994, § 34-80) 
Sec. 32-90. - Contractors to be qualified. 
    Any work for which a permit is issued under the provisions of this division may be performed by the department of public works or with the written permission of the director of public works, by a contractor hired by the permittee, if the contractor is deemed qualified by the director of public works. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-3; Code 1994, § 34-81) 
Sec. 32-91. - Fees. 
(a)  Payment. The applicant for a curb cut or driveway permit shall pay to the director of public works the currently required fee for either residential or commercial property as the case may be. 
(b)  For city work. When the work, for which a curb cut or driveway permit is issued, is performed by the department of public works, the director shall charge any permittees according to the established unit price schedule, which will be updated annually. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-4; Code 1994, § 34-82) 
Sec. 32-92. - Bonds. 
    When a curb cut or driveway opening is made or altered by a contractor hired by the permittee, and if the contractor has previously been responsible for less than satisfactory work according to this division, or the interpretation thereof, by the director of public works, the contractor shall be required to post a bond with the city in the amount of one-half the cost of construction. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-5; Code 1994, § 34-83) 
Sec. 32-93. - Inspections. 
    The director of public works shall conduct or cause to be conducted at least two inspections of each permit issued, the first to take place within five days of the submission of the application as part of the approval process, and shall be a prerequisite to the final approval of the application. The second and final inspection shall take place after the completion of construction upon the director's notification, by the permittee, that the same is ready for inspection. Upon the director's assurance that all work and materials conform to the plans, specifications, and directions, the city will accept the project, and when applicable, release the contractor's bond. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-6; Code 1994, § 34-84) 
Secs. 32-94-32-114. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 32-115. - Size and location of openings. 
(a)  Width of openings. The width of curb cut and driveway openings shall be as follows: 
(1)  The maximum width of any curb cut or driveway opening for any residential purpose shall not exceed 18 feet when designed to accommodate one car, or 24 feet when designed to accommodate two cars. 
(2)  The maximum width of a curb cut or driveway opening for any purpose other than residential shall not exceed 20 feet when designed for one-way traffic, and 34 feet when designed for two-way traffic. 
(3)  For the purpose of this division, the distance of a curb cut, or driveway opening is to figure as a distance from the point of tangency, to the point of tangency of the radius turns or turnstones. 
(b)  Distance to street intersection. The distance of curb cuts and driveway openings from street intersections shall be as follows: 
(1)  No curb cut or driveway opening shall be located within 25 feet of the intersection, of the prolongation of the curblines, unless authorized by the director of public works or traffic division. 
(2)  In no case shall a curb cut or driveway opening be located on the radius corner of any streets, roadway, or highways of the city unless authorized by the director of public works or the traffic division. 
(c)  Distance between curb cuts or driveway openings on same lot. When more than one curb cut or driveway opening is located on the same lot, they shall be separated by a distance of at least 26 feet in areas where curb parking is allowed and at least six feet in areas where curb parking is not allowed. 
(d)  Number permitted. No more than two curb cuts or driveway openings shall be permitted on the street frontage of any lot, except, that three curb cuts or driveway openings may be permitted if the distance between the lot lines within which the curb cuts or driveway openings are located exceeds 185 feet. 
(e)  Distance to the lot line. A curb cut or driveway opening may be constructed beginning directly on the lot line, provided, that all of the restrictions set forth in the zoning ordinance can also be met. 
(f)  Curved curb radius turnstones. Curved curb radius turnstones shall have a two-foot radius, constructed for a 90-degree angle along the tangents, or end of the straight curbing and shall be a minimum of six inches in thickness, and a minimum depth of 18 inches. The type of material used shall be granite or an approved equal. 
(g)  Angle of driveway to property line. No driveway shall be constructed so as to cause an exiting vehicle to cross the driveway opening within the sidewalk area at an angle of less than 45 degrees. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-7; Code 1994, § 34-96) 
Sec. 32-116. - Materials. 
    Materials used in work performed under the provisions of this division shall be those as specified by the director of public works. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-8; Code 1994, § 34-97) 
Sec. 32-117. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  General conditions. The sidewalk is to be kept in a cleared, safe, and passable condition at all times during the construction of a curb cut or driveway opening. 
(b)  Repairs. Any repairs or replacement of the sidewalk necessitated by the construction of a curb cut or driveway opening shall be made within the time period of the curb cut permit; and shall be a prerequisite for the approval of construction and acceptance of the curb cut, or driveway opening, by the city. 
(c)  Materials. The materials and type of construction used in the repair or replacement of sidewalks shall be the same as that which exists on the particular lot. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-9; Code 1994, § 34-98) 
Sec. 32-118. - Safeguards. 
    At all times during which any work under this division is being performed, and until work is completed and approved by the director, the contractor or permittee shall maintain all necessary barriers, lights and other safeguards for the prevention of accidents and for the protection of public and private property. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-10; Code 1994, § 34-99) 
Sec. 32-119. - Removal of rubbish. 
    After all work is completed, the contractor, permittee or other person in charge of such work shall remove all rubbish, waste and excess materials, and leave the street, roadway or highway, in a neat and clean appearing condition. 
(Code 1973, § 16-18-11; Code 1994, § 34-100) 
Secs. 32-120-32-136. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOUSE NUMBERING 

Sec. 32-137. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any owner who fails to affix to and retain number markings on his building in conformity with the standards established in accordance with this article shall, upon conviction by the municipal court, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than $25.00, and to pay all costs associated with prosecution thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 34-123; Ord. of 8-24-1992, § 4) 
Sec. 32-138. - Enforcement of article. 
    Any division of the department of public safety shall have the duty to enforce the requirements contained in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 34-124; Ord. of 8-24-1992, § 3) 
Sec. 32-139. - Duties of public works director. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works to prepare plans for, keep a record of, and assign to all buildings fronting upon every street or public way within the city numbers for such buildings. 
(b)  The director of public works shall prepare and file in the office of the city clerk written standards relating to the number markings to be affixed to and retained on all buildings in accordance with the provisions ordained in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 34-121; Ord. of 8-24-1992, § 1) 
Sec. 32-140. - Duties of building owners. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of buildings located in the city to affix to and retain number markings to such buildings in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  The number markings shall be in color contrast to the building. 
(2)  Each individual number marking shall be no less than two inches in height and one-fourth inch in width. 
(3)  The number markings shall be located either above, below or on the side of the building's front door, but in no event shall the marking be less than three feet from ground level. 
(4)  If the building does not contain a door on its street side, then the number marking shall be located at a place closest in distance to the street. 
(Code 1994, § 34-122; Ord. of 8-24-1992, § 2) 
Secs. 32-141-32-163. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOVING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 32-164. - Permit required. 
    No building shall be moved along, across or through any of the public highways or streets within the city without permission of the city council first had and obtained therefor upon petition made as provided in section 32-165. The permit therefor shall prescribe the streets through, along or across which and the time within which such building shall be removed. 
(Code 1973, § 23-5; Code 1994, § 34-146) 
Sec. 32-165. - Petition for permit. 
    Whenever any person shall desire to remove any building along, across or through any of the streets or public highways in the city, he shall present his petition in writing to the city council for permission to make such removal, which petition shall describe the building, its dimensions, location, the place to which it is desired to be removed and the streets along, across and through which such building is to be removed. Every such petition shall be filed, and the cost of advertising the petition shall be deposited with the city clerk. Such clerk shall cause notice of the pendency of such petition and of the time when the petition will be considered by the council to be publicly advertised for at least one week before action thereon by the council, and all persons interested in the matter of the petition may appear before the council and be heard relative thereto. 
(Code 1973, § 23-6; Code 1994, § 34-147) 
Sec. 32-166. - Owner to pay damages and costs; bond. 
    The owner of every building moved along, across or through the streets of the city shall pay to the city all damages, costs and expenses occasioned to the city by such removal to be ascertained by the city council. Before removing such building, the owner shall give bond to the director of finance in such sum as the city council shall prescribe, satisfactory to the council for the payment of all such costs, damages and expenses so to be ascertained. Such bond shall be further conditioned to pay all costs, damages and expenses that may be caused to the property of or that may be incurred by any person in consequence of such removal. 
(Code 1973, § 23-7; Code 1994, § 34-148) 
Sec. 32-167. - Trimming or moving trees, wires or posts.
