(Code 1973, § 16-3-8; Code 1994, § 38-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-3-1. 
Sec. 36-107. - Display of plates. 
(a)  Registration plates issued for a motor vehicle or other conveyance, other than a motorcycle, trailer, transporter vehicle, in-transit vehicle or bailee engaged in business, or a motor vehicle owned by a duly authorized dealer in motorcycles and which is used in such dealer's business, shall be attached thereto one in the front and the other in the rear. The registration plate issued for a motorcycle, trailer, bailee, and a dealer's motor vehicle shall be attached to the rear thereof. 
(b)  Every registration plate shall at all times be securely fastened in a horizontal position to the vehicle for which it was issued, so as to prevent the plate from swinging at a height of not less than 12 inches from the ground measured from the bottom of such plate, in a place and position to be clearly visible, and shall be maintained free from foreign materials and in a condition to be clearly legible. 
(c)  All vehicles registered as passenger, commercial, trailer, motorcycle, suburban, farm, combination, taxi, radio operator, camper, public, racer tow, jitney, and antique must have displayed on them the registration plate commonly known as the general issuance "wave plate." This subsection does not apply to those registrants in possession of an alternative design plate as described in G.L. 1956, § 31-3-60 or any other specially authorized plate described in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-28; Code 1994, § 38-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-3-18. 
Sec. 36-108. - Driver's license. 
(a)  Every licensee shall have his operator's or chauffeur's license in his or her immediate possession at all times when operating a motor vehicle and shall display the license upon the demand of any peace office or inspector of the state division of motor vehicles and shall, upon request by any proper officer, write his name in the presence of that officer for the purpose of being identified. However, no person charged with violating this section shall be convicted if he produces in court or the office of the arresting officer an operator's or chauffeur's license previously issued to him and valid at the time of his arrest. 
(b)  Every school bus operator shall display in a prominent place in the bus he is operating both a valid chauffeur's license or a reasonable facsimile of it, and a valid school bus driver's certificate, both of which have been issued by this state under the provisions of this article. A display case shall be provided to display these documents by the registered owner. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-19; Code 1994, § 38-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-10-27. 
Sec. 36-109. - Notice of change of address or name to the state. 
    Whenever any person, after applying for and receiving an operator's or chauffeur's license, shall move from the address named in such application or in the license issued to him, or when the name of the licensee is changed due to marriage or otherwise, such person shall, within ten days thereafter, notify the state division of motor vehicles, in writing, of his old and new addresses, or of such former and new names, and of the number of any license then held by him. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-29; Code 1994, § 38-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-10-32. 
Sec. 36-110. - Permitting unauthorized persons to drive. 
    No person shall authorize or knowingly permit a motor vehicle owned by him or under his control to be driven upon any roadway, street or highway of the city by any person who is not authorized to drive such vehicle as set forth by state statutes. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-17; Code 1994, § 38-18) 
Secs. 36-111-36-133. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE OPERATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-134. - Privileges of emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of any law; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an alleged violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in G.L. 1956, § 31-12-7, but subject to the conditions stated in this section and in G.L. 1956, §§ 31-12-8 and 31-12-9. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2-4; Code 1994, § 38-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-12-7, 31-12-6(a). 
Sec. 36-135. - Operation on roadways laned for traffic. 
    Whenever any roadway has been divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for traffic, the following rules in addition to all others consistent with them shall apply: 
(1)  A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practical entirely within a single lane and shall not be moved from the lane until the driver has first ascertained that the movement can be made with safety. 
(2)  Upon a roadway which is divided into three lanes, a vehicle shall not be driven in the center lane except when overtaking and passing another vehicle where the roadway is clearly visible and the center lane is clear of traffic within a safe distance, or in preparation for a left turn or where the center lane is at the time allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the direction the vehicle is proceeding and is sign-posted to give notice of the allocation. 
(3)  If official signs are erected directing slow-moving traffic to use a designated lane or designating those lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the roadway, drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of the signs. 
(Code 1973, § 16-4-10; Code 1994, § 38-51(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-11. 
Sec. 36-136. - Driving through safety zone. 
    No vehicle shall, at any time, be driven through or within a safety zone. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-10; Code 1994, § 38-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-22-5. 
Sec. 36-137. - Operation on play streets. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle upon any play street, or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business, or whose residences are within such closed areas, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 16-4-7; Code 1994, § 38-48) 
Sec. 36-138. - Driving on limited access roadway. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from any limited-access roadway, street or highway, except at such entrances and exits as are established by the public authority. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-11; Code 1994, § 38-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-14. 
Sec. 36-139. - Restrictions upon use of streets by certain vehicles. 
(a)  The city traffic division and public safety director are hereby authorized to determine and designate those heavily traveled streets, or parts thereof, upon which shall be prohibited the use of the roadway by motor-driven cycles, bicycles, horse-drawn vehicles, or other nonmotorized traffic, and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  When signs are so erected giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the restrictions stated in such signs and so stated in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-17-4; Code 1994, § 38-113) 
Sec. 36-140. - One-way streets. 
(a)  Upon those streets, roadways and highways, or parts thereof, and in those alleys designated as being one-way, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction, when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle on any one-way streets or highways, except in the places designated. 
(Code 1973, §§ 16-3-24, 16-7-2; Code 1994, §§ 38-123, 38-182) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsection (a)), G.L. 1956, §31-15-9; authority to establish one-way streets, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(4). 
Sec. 36-141. - Intervals between vehicles. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard of the speed of such vehicles and traffic, and conditions of the roadway, street or highway, and shall, whenever traveling within a business or residential district, and whenever traffic permits, leave sufficient space so that an overtaking vehicle may enter and occupy such space without danger. This provision shall not apply to a caravan under escort, or to a funeral procession. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-15; Code 1994, § 38-119) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-12. 
Secs. 36-142-36-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION ON RIGHT SIDE OF ROAD; OVERTAKING AND PASSING 

Sec. 36-166. - Passing of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions. 
    Drivers of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right, and upon roadways having width for more than one line of traffic in each direction. Each driver shall give to the other at least one-half of the main traveled portion of the roadway, as nearly as possible. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-10; Code 1994, § 38-114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-3. 
Sec. 36-167. - Overtaking on the left. 
    The following rules shall govern overtaking of vehicles proceeding in the same direction, subject to the limitations, exceptions and special rules stated in this section: 
(1)  The driver of a vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall give a timely audible signal, and shall pass to the left thereof at a safe distance, and shall not again drive to the right of the roadway until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle. 
(2)  Except when overtaking and passing to the right is permitted, the driver of the overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right, in favor of the overtaking vehicle on audible signal, and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-12; Code 1994, § 38-116 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-4. 
Sec. 36-168. - Overtaking on the right. 
(a)  The driver of a motor vehicle may overtake and pass on the right of another vehicle only under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left turn. 
(2)  Upon a one-way street, or upon any roadway on which traffic is restricted to one direction of movement, where the roadway is free from obstructions and of sufficient width to allow for two or more lines of moving vehicles. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle proceeding in the same direction upon the right only under conditions permitting such movement in safety. In no event shall such movement be made by driving off the pavement or traveled portion of the roadway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-11; Code 1994, § 38-115) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-5. 
Sec. 36-169. - Clearance for overtaking. 
    No vehicle shall be driven to the left of the center of the roadway in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless such left-hand portion of the roadway is completely visible and is free of oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing to be completely made without interfering with the safe operation of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction, or any vehicle overtaken. In every event, the overtaking vehicle must return to the right side of the roadway before coming within 100 feet of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-22; Code 1994, § 38-122) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-6. 
Sec. 36-170. - Places where overtaking prohibited. 
(a)  No vehicle shall, at any time, be driven to the left of the roadway, street or highway under the following conditions: 
(1)  When approaching the crest of a grade, or upon a curve in the highway, where the driver's view is obstructed within such distance as to create a hazard in the event another vehicle might approach in the opposite direction. 
(2)  When approaching within 100 feet of, or traversing, any intersection or railroad crossing. 
(3)  When the view is obstructed upon approaching within 100 feet of any bridge. 
(b)  The limitations in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply upon a one-way street, roadway or highway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-14; Code 1994, § 38-118) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-7. 
Secs. 36-171-36-193. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SPEED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions, G.L. 1956, § 31-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 36-194. - State speed laws applicable; posted speed limits. 
    The state laws regulating the speeding of vehicles shall be applicable upon all roadways, streets and highways within the city, except as provided under G.L. 1956, § 31-14-5, in which event it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of any speed so declared by this division, when signs are in place giving notice thereof. Those roadways, streets and highways, or parts thereof so designated by the city traffic division are hereby regulated by posted speeds. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5-1; Code 1994, § 38-141) 
Sec. 36-195. - Regulation of speed by traffic signals; obedience to posted speed signs. 
(a)  The city traffic division is hereby authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner, at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the district, or at intersections, and erect appropriate signs or signals giving notice thereof. 
(b)  The city traffic division shall hereby have the authority to regulate speed conditions on streets deemed hazardous and unsafe by traffic, pedestrians, or other investigations, so that certain speed regulations shall be applicable upon specified streets, or in certain areas, in which event it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle or other conveyance at a speed in excess of any speed so declared in this division when signs are in place giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5-2; Code 1994, § 38-142) 
Sec. 36-196. - Reasonable and prudent speeds; penalty for violation. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle or conveyance upon a roadway, street or highway of the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions, and having regard to the actual and potential hazards thereof. In any event, speed shall be controlled as may be deemed necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle, or other conveyance, on, or entering, the roadway, street or highway, in compliance with all legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall carry the following penalties: 
(1)  One to ten miles per hour over the speed limit: $50.00. 
(2)  Eleven or more miles per hour over the speed limit will require a municipal court appearance. Upon a plea or finding of guilty, such violator may be fined, but not limited to, $10.00 per mile for each and every mile per hour over the speed limit. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5-3; Code 1994, § 38-143) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-14-1. 
Sec. 36-197. - Slow traffic. 
    Upon all roadways, streets and highways of the city, any vehicle proceeding at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall be driven in the right-hand lane, if available for traffic, or as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, street or highway, except when overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction, or when preparing for a left turn at an intersection, or a turn into a private road or driveway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5-4; Code 1994, § 38-144) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-2. 
Secs. 36-198-36-217. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RIGHT-OF-WAY; STOP SIGNS; YIELD SIGNS 

Sec. 36-218. - Yielding to emergency vehicle. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle equipped with at least one lighted lamp exhibiting any one or combination of red, blue, or white light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle, and producing an audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle, or bell, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right-hand edge or curb of the roadway clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in that position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2-4; Code 1994, § 38-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-17-6. 
Sec. 36-219. - Right-of-way in absence of signs or signals. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from a different roadway, street or highway. 
(b)  When two vehicles enter an intersection from different roadways, streets or highways at approximately the same time, the driver on the left shall yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right. 
(c)  The right-of-way rules declared in subsections (a) and (b) of this section are modified at through roadways, and as otherwise stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-9; Code 1994, § 38-209) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 31-17-1. 
Sec. 36-220. - Obedience to stop and yield signs. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign is required to stop before entering the crosswalk, on the near side of the intersection, or, if there is no crosswalk, at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. 
(b)  Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic control signal, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or, if there is no crosswalk, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway, before entering the intersection. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-3; Code 1994, § 38-203) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsection (b)), G.L. 1956, § 31-20-9. 
Sec. 36-221. - Vehicles entering stop intersection. 
    Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or, if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian intending to cross the lane of traffic in a crosswalk or any vehicle which has entered the intersection from another highway or which is approaching so closely on the highway as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when the driver is moving across or within the intersection. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-4; Code 1994, § 38-204) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-7-4(b). 
Sec. 36-222. - Vehicles entering yield intersection. 
    The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall, in obedience to the sign, slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and, if required for safety to stop, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or, if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. After slowing or stopping, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian intending to cross the lane of traffic in a crosswalk or any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time the driver is moving across or within the intersection. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-5; Code 1994, § 38-205) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-7-4(c). 
Sec. 36-223. - Signs required at through streets. 
    Whenever any ordinance of the city designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the traffic division to place and maintain a stop or, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation at any intersection, a yield sign, on each and every street and roadway intersecting such through street, unless traffic at any such intersection is controlled at all times by traffic control signals; provided, however, that at the intersection of two such through streets or at the intersection of a through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall be erected at the approaches of either of such streets, as may be determined by the city traffic division upon the basis of an engineering and traffic study. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-1; Code 1994, § 38-201) 
Sec. 36-224. - Through streets designated. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as through streets: 
(1)  Broad Street, from the Pawtucket city line north to the Cumberland town line. 
(2)  Dexter Street, from the Pawtucket city line north to Lonsdale Avenue. 
(3)  Lonsdale Avenue, from the Pawtucket city line north to the Lincoln town line. 
(4)  Roosevelt Avenue, from the Pawtucket city line north to the Pawtucket city line. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-10; Code 1994, § 38-210) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate through streets, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(6). 
Secs. 36-225-36-241. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TURNING AND SIGNALING 

Sec. 36-242. - Required position and method of turning at intersections. 
(a)  Right turns are as follows: 
(1)  Both the approach for the right turn, and a right turn, shall be made as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, street or highway. 
(2)  Pedestrians intending to cross a lane of traffic which is required to stop or yield by a red traffic light, stop or yield sign or other traffic control device shall be granted the right-of-way. 
(b)  Left turns onto two-way streets are as follows: 
(1)  At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both directions on each roadway entering the intersection, an approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof, and bypassing to the right of such centerline where it enters the intersection, and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made within that portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the intersection. 
(2)  Pedestrians intending to cross a lane of traffic which is required to stop or yield by a red traffic light, stop or yield sign or other traffic control device shall be granted the right-of-way. 
(c)  Left turns onto other than two-way roadways: 
(1)  At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on one or more of the roadways, the driver of the vehicle intending to turn left at any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle, and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the roadway being entered. 
(2)  Pedestrians intending to cross a lane of traffic which is required to stop or yield by a red traffic light, stop or yield sign, or other traffic control device, shall be granted the right-of-way. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-1; Code 1994, § 38-161) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-2. 
Sec. 36-243. - Obedience to turning markers, authority to place. 
    When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the direction of such indications. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-2; Code 1994, § 38-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-3. 
Sec. 36-244. - Obedience to no-turn signs. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left, or U-turns are permitted, no driver of a vehicle or conveyance shall disobey the directions of such signs. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-4; Code 1994, § 38-164) 
State Law reference- Obedience to traffic control devices, G.L. 1956, § 31-13-4. 
Sec. 36-245. - Limitations on turning around. 
    The driver of any vehicle or conveyance shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any roadway, street or highway in a business district, and shall not, upon any other street, so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-5; Code 1994, § 38-165) 
State Law reference- U-turns generally, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-4; authority to regulate turns, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(9). 
Sec. 36-246. - Prohibited turning movements. 
    Restricted turning movements are hereby established within the city and made a part of this division, in which case the turning of vehicles and/or conveyances upon the roadways, streets or highways of the city are prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-6; Code 1994, § 38-166) 
Sec. 36-247. - Method of turning; use of turn signals. 
(a)  No person shall turn a vehicle at an intersection unless the vehicle is in proper position upon the roadway, as required in the general laws of the state, or turn a vehicle to enter a private road or driveway, or otherwise turn a vehicle from a direct course, or move right or left upon a roadway, unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. 
(b)  No person shall turn any vehicle or conveyance without giving an appropriate signal in the manner provided in this division, if any other traffic may be affected by such movement. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-7; Code 1994, § 38-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsection (a)), G.L. 1956, § 31-16-5. 
Sec. 36-248. - Time of signaling turn. 
    A signal of intention to turn right or left when required shall be given continuously during not less than the last 100 feet traveled by the vehicle before turning. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-7; Code 1994, § 38-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-6. 
Sec. 36-249. - Method of giving signals. 
    Any stop or turn signal when required in this division shall be given either by means of the hand and arm or by a signal lamp or mechanical signal device, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-7; Code 1994, § 38-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-8. 
Sec. 36-250. - Vehicles on which mechanical signal devices required. 
    Any motor vehicle in use on a highway shall be equipped with, and required signal shall be given by, a signal lamp or mechanical signal device when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the left outside limit of the body, cab, or load of the motor vehicle exceeds 24 inches, or when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the rear limit of the body or load of it exceeds 14 feet. The latter measurement shall apply to any single vehicle, and/or to any combination of vehicles. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-7; Code 1994, § 38-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-9. 
Sec. 36-251. - Manner of giving arm signals. 
    All signals required in this division when given by hand and arm shall be given from the left side of the vehicle in the following manner and the signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  Left turn: Hand and arm extended horizontally; 
(2)  Right turn: Hand and arm extended upward; 
(3)  Stop or decrease speed: Hand and arm extended downward. 
(Code 1973, § 16-6-7; Code 1994, § 38-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-9. 
Secs. 36-252-36-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SPECIAL STOPS 

Sec. 36-281. - Emerging from alley, driveway or building. 
    The driver of a vehicle within a business or residential district, emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk, or onto a sidewalk area extending across any alley or driveway, and shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision; and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway, street or highway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-6; Code 1994, § 38-206) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-20-10. 
Sec. 36-282. - Entering intersection or crosswalk when traffic obstructed. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-7; Code 1994, § 38-207) 
Sec. 36-283. - Obedience to signal indicating approach of train. 
(a)  Whenever a person driving a vehicle approaches a railroad grade crossing under any of the circumstances stated in this section, the driver of such vehicle shall stop within 50 feet, but not less than 15 feet, from the nearest rail of such railroad, and shall not proceed until he can do so safely. The foregoing requirements shall apply when: 
(1)  A clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a railroad train. 
(2)  A crossing gate is lowered, or when a human flagman gives or continues to give a signal of the approach or passage of a railroad train. 
(3)  A railroad train approaching within approximately 1,500 feet of the roadway, street or highway crossing emits a signal audible from a distance and such railroad train, by reason of its speed or nearness to such crossing, is an immediate hazard. 
(4)  An approaching railroad train is plainly visible and is in hazardous proximity to such crossing. 
(b)  No person shall drive any vehicle or conveyance through, around or under any crossing gate or barrier that is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(Code 1973, § 16-8-8; Code 1994, § 38-208) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-20-1, 31-20-2. 
Secs. 36-284-36-314. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PROCESSIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on highways, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(3). 

Sec. 36-315. - Driving through a funeral or other procession. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while such procession is in motion, and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required by this division. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signs or police officers. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-3; Code 1994, § 38-83) 
State Law reference- Driving between vehicles in funeral processions, G.L. 1956, § 31-27-16. 
Sec. 36-316. - Driving in a procession. 
    Each driver of a vehicle in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway, street or highway as practicable, and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-4; Code 1994, § 38-84) 
Sec. 36-317. - Funeral processions to be identified. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia, or by the display of the vehicles' headlights and taillights in operation, or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the traffic division. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-5; Code 1994, § 38-85) 
Secs. 36-318-36-337. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 36-338. - Starting parked vehicle. 
    No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless or until such movement can be done with reasonable safety. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-20; Code 1994, § 38-121) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-16-1. 
Sec. 36-339. - Following fire apparatus. 
    The driver of any vehicle other than one on official business shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than 500 feet, or drive into or park such vehicle within the block area where such fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-1; Code 1994, § 38-81) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-22-7. 
Sec. 36-340. - Crossing fire hose. 
    No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire department, when laid down on any roadway, street or highway, or private driveway, to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department officer in command. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-2; Code 1994, § 38-82) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-22-7. 
Sec. 36-341. - Vehicles not to be operated over streets closed for repairs. 
    No person shall drive, or cause to be driven, any vehicle over that roadway, street or highway, or part thereof, which is being mended, repaired or paved, if such street, roadway or highway is wholly closed to travel. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-26; Code 1994, § 38-125) 
Sec. 36-342. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive upon or within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-6; Code 1994, § 38-86) 
State Law reference- Right-of-way on sidewalks, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-18; stop when crossing sidewalk, G.L. 1956, § 31-20-10. 
Sec. 36-343. - Restrictions on backing. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back such vehicle unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-7; Code 1994, § 38-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-22-2. 
Sec. 36-344. - Turning and backing prohibited on certain streets. 
    No person shall turn around or back up, or cause to be turned around or backed up, any vehicle into any of the following specified streets, except in an emergency: Broad Street, Dexter Street, Lonsdale Avenue, Roosevelt Avenue. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-25; Code 1994, § 38-124) 
Sec. 36-345. - Coasting prohibited. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle, when traveling upon a downgrade, shall not coast with the gears of such vehicle in neutral. The driver of a commercial vehicle, when traveling upon a downgrade, shall not coast with the clutch disengaged. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-18; Code 1994, § 38-120) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-22-6. 
Secs. 36-346-36-363. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, G.L. 1956, § 31-21-1 et seq.; violation of parking regulations, G.L. 1956, § 12-14-12; authority to regulate standing or parking of vehicles, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(1). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-364. - Application of article. 
    The provisions of this article prohibiting the standing, stopping and/or parking of a vehicle or conveyance shall apply at all times, or at those times specified in this article, or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-1; Code 1994, § 38-250) 
Sec. 36-365. - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles or conveyances in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-2; Code 1994, § 38-251) 
Sec. 36-366. - Parking signs required. 
    Whenever, by this article or any other ordinance of the city, any parking time limit is imposed, or parking is prohibited on designated roadways or in municipal parking lots, it shall be the duty of the city traffic division to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of the alleged offense. 
    Except that no such signs shall be required for the prohibition of parking or leaving of a vehicle of any type unattended on any street, road alley, lane, thoroughfare, park or public grounds in the City of Central Falls during the period of December 1st through April 1st of the next year between the hours of 1:00 am and 6:00 am. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-8; Code 1994, § 38-257; Ord. of 12-19-2011(2) ) 
Sec. 36-367. - Measurements controlling parking and prohibited parking areas. 
    Whenever there appears, in this article, a reference to the distance along one street, or from the intersection of another street, then such measurement shall be construed to mean the point of tangency of the curve of such street in question and along such street the appropriate distance stated. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-10; Code 1994, § 38-260) 
Sec. 36-368. - Parking privileges for disabled. 
    No penalty shall be imposed upon any person with a disability issued a disability parking privilege placard or sticker pursuant to G.L. 1956, §§ 31-28-7, 31-27-7.1 or 31-29-5, nor from the motor vehicle transporting the person with a disability, provided that upon that vehicle there is displayed a disability parking placard or sticker for parking on the highways or in a space for a longer period of time than other persons are permitted to park on the highways or in a space. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to authorize that person to park in any place at any time where parking is prohibited. 
Sec. 36-369. - Standing or parking close to curb. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway, street or highway in the city where there are adjacent curbs shall be stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way street, roadway or highway in the city, where there are adjacent curbs and left-hand parking is permitted upon such a roadway, shall be so stopped or parked with the left-hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the left-hand curb. 
(Code 1973, § 16-12-1; Code 1994, § 38-231) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsection (a)), G.L. 1956, § 31-21-7; authority to provide (as provided in subsection (b)), G.L. 1956, § 31-21-8. 
Sec. 36-370. - Obedience to angle parking signs and markings. 
    On those streets which have been signed or marked by the city traffic division for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(Code 1973, § 16-12-3; Code 1994, § 38-233) 
Sec. 36-371. - Parking not to obstruct traffic. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon a roadway, street or highway, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of such roadway, street or highway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-2; Code 1994, § 38-235) 
Sec. 36-372. - Vehicles obstructing the roadway. 
    The operator of a truck, semitrailer or tractor-trailer shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle at any time for the purpose of loading or unloading debris, construction materials, merchandise or equipment, so as to obstruct more than one-half of the traveled roadway, street or highway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-13; Code 1994, § 38-93) 
Sec. 36-373. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within eight feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(7)  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb, or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the traffic authority indicates a different length by signs or markings; 
(9)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(10)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance (when properly sign-posted); 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping; 
(15)  At any curb cut or ramp for persons with disabilities; 
(16)  On any bicycle lane, trail or path; 
(17)  Upon any crosshatched access aisle adjacent to disability parking spaces; 
(18)  At an angle with the curbing where legal parking is permitted, unless otherwise indicated by signs and/or markings; 
(19)  Parallel with any curbing that is painted yellow; 
(20)  In any prohibited parking area of a municipal parking lot, when posted; or 
(21)  With the left wheels thereof next to the curb. 
(b)  The following vehicles are exempt from the prohibitions contained in subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  School buses or worker transport buses that are loading or unloading children or workers, provided that the school bus or worker transport bus operates its flashing bus safety lights; 
(2)  Subject to the provisions of G.L. 1956, § 31-21-6, vehicles that are momentarily stopped, standing, or parked to admit or discharge passengers; 
(3)  Vehicles that are momentarily stopped, standing, or parked for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property; 
(4)  Vehicles that are owned or operated by the state or a city or town when the vehicle must stop, stand, or park to perform maintenance or repair work on an area where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section; 
(5)  Vehicles that are disabled in such a manner and to such extent that the vehicle operator cannot avoid stopping or temporarily leaving the disabled vehicle in an area where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section; 
(6)  Vehicles that are momentarily stopped to allow oncoming traffic to pass before making a right or left-hand turn, or in preparation for or while negotiating an exit from the road. 
(c)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any prohibited parking area, or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-1; Code 1994, § 38-234) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-21-4, 31-21-5. 
Sec. 36-374. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway, street or highway of the city for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Displaying of commercial advertising signs on any parked vehicles for the purpose of directing customers to any business establishment. 
(3)  Washing, greasing or repairing of vehicles, except repairs necessitated by emergency. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-3; Code 1994, § 38-236) 
Sec. 36-375. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The city traffic division is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property, when such parking, in their opinion, interferes with traffic or creates a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of a street adjacent to any school property, as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle or conveyance in any such designated place. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-4; Code 1994, § 38-237) 
Sec. 36-376. - Parking prohibited on narrow streets. 
(a)  The city traffic division is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking, either side, on two-way streets when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet, or upon one side of a street, as indicated by such signs, when the width of the roadway does not exceed 30 feet. 
(b)  When official signs are erected prohibiting parking on narrow streets, as authorized in this section, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of such sign. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-5; Code 1994, § 38-238) 
Sec. 36-377. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. 
    The city traffic division is hereby authorized to erect signs upon the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park any vehicle or conveyance upon such left-hand side in violation of such sign. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-6; Code 1994, § 38-239) 
Sec. 36-378. - No stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested areas. 
    When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places, as authorized in this section, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle or conveyance in any such designated place or area. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-7; Code 1994, § 38-240(b)) 
Sec. 36-379. - Parking of commercial vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall park a commercial vehicle upon any roadway or street of any residential district between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  No person shall park or cause to be parked upon any roadway, street or highway of the city a vehicle with a load capacity in excess of three-fourths of a ton. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-8; Code 1994, § 38-241) 
Sec. 36-380. - Parking on private property. 
    To stop illegal parking on private property, and the inconvenience to homeowners, the following method is hereby established: 
(1)  The owner or caretaker of the private property shall sign an official complaint with the police department designating the illegally parked vehicle and the registration number and physical description thereof. 
(2)  The police department shall tow, or cause to be towed, such vehicle, and such vehicle shall be impounded and stored with the towing company. The cost of such towing and storage of such vehicle shall be paid by the last registered owner of such vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 16-13-9; Code 1994, § 38-242) 
Sec. 36-381. - Parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets described in such schedule of streets and made part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-3; Code 1994, § 38-252) 
Sec. 36-382. - Parking prohibited during certain times on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours or days specified upon any streets described in such schedule of streets and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-4; Code 1994, § 38-253) 
Sec. 36-383. - Stopping, standing, parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time upon the streets described in such schedule of streets and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-5; Code 1994, § 38-254) 
Sec. 36-384. - Stopping, standing, parking prohibited at certain times on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the hours specified, upon any of the streets described in such schedule of streets and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-6; Code 1994, § 38-255) 
Sec. 36-385. - Parking time limited on certain streets and municipal parking lots. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the hours specified in the municipal parking lots, or upon those streets described in such schedule of streets and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-15-7; Code 1994, § 38-256) 
Sec. 36-386. - Vehicles stopping in roadway. 
    The operator of a vehicle shall not stop such vehicle in the traveled portion of the roadway, street or highway of the city for the purpose of conducting a conversation, dropping off passengers, or picking up passengers, thereby interfering with the normal flow of traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-15; Code 1994, § 38-95; Ord. of 3-14-2005(2)) 
Sec. 36-387. - Winter parking ban on city streets. 
(1)  No person shall park or leave unattended a vehicle of any type on any street, road, alley, lane, thoroughfare, park or public grounds in the City of Central Falls during the period of December 1st through April 1st of the next year between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  The parking or leaving of any vehicle in violation of this section shall subject the owner of the vehicle any and all sanctions and fines imposed for violations of city parking ordinances including but not limited to; section 36-440 of the Code of Ordinances empowering the chief of police the authority to summarily remove or cause to be removed any vehicle in violation of this ordinance. 
(3)  Any vehicle so removed may be redeemed by the owner of said vehicle upon payment of all towing charges, storage charges and other expenses as required by law. 
(Ord. of 12-19-2011(3) ) 
Secs. 36-388-36-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOADING ZONES, TAXICAB STANDS, ETC. 

Sec. 36-416. - Standing in passenger curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone or bus stop, during hours when the regulations are applicable to such curb zone. 
(Code 1973, § 16-14-2; Code 1994, § 38-244) 
Sec. 36-417. - Standing in freight curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, other than a registered commercial vehicle, for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery, or pickup, and loading of materials, in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone, during hours when the regulations are applicable to such zone. 
(Code 1973, § 16-14-3; Code 1994, § 38-245) 
Sec. 36-418. - Stopping, standing, parking of buses and taxicabs regulated. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any roadway, street or highway at any place other than a bus stop or stand so designated as provided in this division. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any roadway at any place for the purpose of loading/unloading passengers and/or baggage other than at a bus stop or passenger loading zone so designated as provided in this division, except in cases of emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop on a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers and/or baggage, shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than 18 inches from the curb, and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to impede the movement of vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any roadway at any place other than in a stand so designated in this division. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations, for the purpose of expeditious loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1973, § 16-14-6; Code 1994, § 38-248) 
Sec. 36-419. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or stand, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the loading or unloading of passengers, when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1973, § 16-14-7; Code 1994, § 38-249) 
Secs. 36-420-36-436. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SNOWSTORM EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 36-437. - Implementation of emergency parking ban. 
    Whenever the forecast by the United States Weather Bureau or any other special weather service predicts a snowstorm disturbance of severity for this area*, it shall be the duty of the public safety director and/or the chief of police to declare an emergency parking ban, for the purpose of preservation of the public safety and/or the removal of snow, ice, sleet, and/or slush, on all public streets, roadways or highways of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 16-19-1; Code 1994, § 38-291; Ord. of 9-14-2015(1) , § 1) 
Sec. 36-438. - Parking prohibited during/after certain snowstorms. 
    All parking is prohibited on all roadways, streets or highways of the city between the hours of 12:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. during the months of November, December, January, February and March during a snowstorm whenever the snow may reach a depth of two or more inches, and whenever such parking occurs less than six hours after such snowstorm of such two-inch depth. 
(Code 1973, § 16-19-2; Code 1994, § 38-292; Ord. of 12-14-1987(3), § 1; Ord. of 9-14-2015(1) , § 1) 
Sec. 36-439. - Parking interfering with the removal of snow, ice and slush prohibited. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle, or other conveyance or other vehicle by whatsoever means propelled, so as to interfere with the orderly removal of snow, ice, slush, etc., from the roadways, streets or highways of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 16-19-3; Code 1994, § 38-293; Ord. of 12-14-1987(3), § 1; Ord. of 9-14-2015(1) , § 1) 
Sec. 36-440. - Removal of vehicles. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized and shall summarily remove, or cause to be removed, from the roadways, streets or highways of the city, as well as public places, any vehicle, by whatsoever means propelled, which is parked or located in violation of the provisions of this division, or any other traffic ordinance of the city, or whenever such vehicle shall interfere with the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-19-5; Code 1994, § 38-295; Ord. of 12-14-1987(3), § 1; Ord. of 9-14-2015(1) , § 1) 
Sec. 36-441. - Penalties. 
    In addition to the potential removal of a vehicle pursuant to section 36-440, the penalty for the first violation of this division shall be a fine of $100.00. A second violation of this division shall be a fine of $200.00 and a third violation shall be a fine of $500.00. Each fine shall be appealable to the municipal court. 
(Ord. of 9-14-2015(1) , § 1) 
Secs. 36-442-36-463. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BICYCLES AND SIMILAR VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of bicycles, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate bicycles, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12(a)(8). 

Sec. 36-464. - Effect of article. 
(a)  It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this article. 
(b)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize, or knowingly permit, any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The regulations in this article applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any roadway, street or highway of the city, or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-1; Code 1994, § 38-341) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsections (a) and (b)), G.L. 1956, §§ 31-19-1, 31-19-2. 
Sec. 36-465. - Traffic laws applicable to persons riding bicycles. 
    Every person riding an electric personal assistive mobility device ("EPAMD"), riding an electric motorized bicycle, or propelling a vehicle by human power shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle, except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as to those provisions of which by their nature can have no application. This section shall not forbid a bicyclist, EPAMD or electric motorized bicycle from traveling upon the shoulders of the highway except for those highways which prohibit bicyclists; provided, that an EPAMD shall possess all the rights and obligations of a pedestrian, but shall not have the rights and responsibilities of the operator of a motor vehicle and that cities and towns may regulate the operation of an EPAMD. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-2; Code 1994, § 38-342) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-3. 
Sec. 36-466. - Obedience to traffic control devices. 
(a)  Any person operating a bicycle shall have to obey the instructions of official traffic control signs, signals and other control devices applicable to vehicles and conveyances, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-3; Code 1994, § 38-343) 
Sec. 36-467. - Riding on roadways, streets or highways. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway, street or highway in the city shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction except where official traffic control devices (signs or pavement markings) specifically direct bicyclists to do otherwise. 
(b)  Persons riding a bicycle upon a roadway, street or highway in the city shall not ride more than two abreast except on bicycle trails or paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Persons riding two abreast shall not unduly impede traffic and, on a laned roadway, shall ride within a single lane. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-4; Code 1994, § 38-344) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-9-6, 31-9-7. 
Sec. 36-468. - Motorized devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized device on any public sidewalk or street. For the purpose of this section, the term "motorized device" means a device that may be propelled by human power or helper power or both, with a motor rated not more than 11/2 brake horsepower or two (S.A.E.) horsepower, which is capable of a maximum speed of not more than 30 miles per hour, except for devices that are moved exclusively by human power, or electric personal assisted mobility devices, including segways and authorized wheelchairs. 
(Code 1994, § 38-354; Ord. of 8-31-2004(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-5. 
Sec. 36-469. - Riding on controlled-access highways. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle on any roadway, or the areas adjacent to the roadways, of a controlled-access highway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-5; Code 1994, § 38-345) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, G.L. 1956, § 31-15-15. 
Sec. 36-470. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district. 
(b)  No person 15 or more years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in any district. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-10; Code 1994, § 38-350(a), (b)) 
Sec. 36-471. - Bicycles on sidewalks and crosswalks; rights and duties. 
    A person propelling a vehicle by human power or operating an electric personal assistive mobility device ("EPAMD") upon and along a sidewalk, or across a roadway upon and along a crosswalk, shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to a pedestrian under the same circumstances; provided, however, that a person riding an EPAMD on a sidewalk or a bicycle path or trail shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians or give an audible signal before overtaking any passing pedestrian. Pedestrians using an EPAMD shall exercise a high degree of care when passing a pedestrian using a wheelchair, walker or other mobility aid and only pass when the width of the sidewalk exceeds five feet. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-10; Code 1994, § 38-350(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-12. 
Sec. 36-472. - Riding on bicycles. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride upon or astride other than a permanent and regular seat attached to such bicycle. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed or equipped, except when transporting a child six years of age or younger in a rear-mounted bicycle carrier and/or trailer that meets mandatory and various industry standard specifications as developed by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM). 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-11; Code 1994, § 38-351) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-4. 
Sec. 36-473. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-6; Code 1994, § 38-346) 
Sec. 36-474. - Emerging from alley or driveway. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway or driveway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-7; Code 1994, § 38-347) 
Sec. 36-475. - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or other article which prevents the use of both hands in the control and operation of the bicycle. A person operating a bicycle shall keep at least one hand on the handlebars at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-8; Code 1994, § 38-348) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-9. 
Sec. 36-476. - Clinging to vehicles. 
(a)  No person riding upon a bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled, or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon any roadway. 
(b)  This section shall not prohibit attaching a trailer or semitrailer to a bicycle if that trailer or semitrailer has been designed for this attachment. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-12; Code 1994, § 38-353) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-5. 
Sec. 36-477. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street, roadway or highway other than upon the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack support for the bicycle, or against a building, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-9; Code 1994, § 38-349) 
Sec. 36-478. - Lamps and other equipment on bicycles. 
(a)  Front lamp. Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front. 
(b)  Rear reflector. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a red reflector of a type approved by the state division of motor vehicles which shall be visible for 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(c)  Pedal reflectors. No person shall sell a new bicycle or a pedal for use on a bicycle that is not equipped with a reflector of a type approved by the state, on each pedal of the bicycle which is visible from the front and rear of the bicycle during darkness from a distance of 200 feet nor shall any person operate a bicycle without reflective pedals. 
(d)  Sirens or whistles. A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use a bicycle equipped with, a siren or whistle. 
(e)  Brakes. No person shall sell a bicycle, new or used, that is not equipped, and every bicycle, excluding bicycles that are especially designed and made for off-road use, shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to stop the bicycle within 25 feet at a speed of ten miles per hour on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(f)  Side reflectors. Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a minimum of 20 square inches on each side of the bicycle of white reflective material on the wheels or tires to indicate as nearly as possible the continuous circular shape and size of the wheels or tires of each bicycle. All reflective materials used in compliance with this statute shall be visible during the hours of darkness from 500 feet when viewed under lawful low beam headlamps under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway, and shall meet the requirements as prescribed by the state division of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1973, § 16-11-13; Code 1994, § 38-352) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-19-10. 
Secs. 36-479-36-509. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MOTORCYCLES 

Sec. 36-510. - Riding on motorcycles. 
(a)  A person operating a motorcycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached to it. The operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a motorcycle unless the motorcycle is designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the rear or side of the operator. 
(b)  In no event shall a motorcycle passenger ride in front of the operator. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-9; Code 1994, § 38-89) 
Sec. 36-511. - Required equipment. 
    Operators of motorcycles, motor scooters, and motor-driven cycles shall use eye protection of a type approved by the administrator of the division of motor vehicles when operating their vehicles on streets and highways. Every motorcycle, motor scooter, and motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with a rear view mirror. Any operator under the age of 21 shall wear a helmet of a type approved by the state administrator of motor vehicles. In addition, all new operators, regardless of age, shall be required, for a period of one year from the date of issuance of the first license pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 31-10.1-1, to wear a helmet of a type approved by said administrator. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-21; Code 1994, § 38-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-10.1-4. 
Sec. 36-512. - Handlebars. 
    No person shall operate on a highway or in any parking area for ten or more motor vehicles, any motorcycle, motor scooter, or motor driven cycle equipped with handlebars that are more than 15 inches in height above the uppermost portion of the seat when depressed by the weight of the operator. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-21; Code 1994, § 38-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-10.1-5. 
Sec. 36-513. - Passengers. 
    Any passenger on a motorcycle, motor scooter, or motor-driven cycle must be provided with a separate rear seat, a separate foot-rest, and an appropriate handlebar or grip for his use, and must wear a properly fitting helmet of a type approved by the administrator of the division of motor vehicles. No person shall operate a motorcycle, motor scooter, or motor-driven cycle unless any passenger on it wears a helmet and is able to rest his feet upon a foot-rest. Any passenger on a motorcycle, motor scooter, or motor-driven cycle under 12 years of age must have a properly secured back-rest or equivalent, shall have his feet placed upon the foot-rest, and shall be seated behind the operator unless a side car is provided. When, however, a side car is provided this age requirement shall not apply to any passenger in the sidecar. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-21; Code 1994, § 38-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-10.1-6. 
Secs. 36-514-36-534. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 36-535. - Due care by drivers. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian or any person propelling a human-powered vehicle upon any roadway, and shall give an audible signal when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution, upon observing any child or any obviously confused, intoxicated or incapacitated person. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3-9; Code 1994, § 38-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-8. 
Sec. 36-536. - Pedestrians subject to traffic control signals. 
    Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals, as declared in sections 36-76 and 36-77, but at all other places, pedestrians shall be granted those rights, and be subject to the restrictions, stated in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-1; Code 1994, § 38-311) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-1. 
Sec. 36-537. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic control signals are not in place, or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle or conveyance shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway, street or highway within a crosswalk, when the pedestrian is upon the half of such roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. No pedestrian shall suddenly leave the curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the conditions stated in G.L. 1956, § 31-18-6. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-2; Code 1994, § 38-312(a)-(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-3. 
Sec. 36-538. - Obstruction of walkways. 
    No person shall stand on any footwalk, sidewalk, doorway, doorstep or driveway in such a manner so as to cause obstruction, hindrance, delay, disturbance or annoyance to any passerby or other persons residing or doing business in the vicinity. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2-5; Code 1994, § 38-6) 
Sec. 36-539. - Overtaking of vehicles stopped for pedestrians. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, street or highway, the driver of any vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever there are no markings to the contrary, there shall be a presumption that there is an unmarked crosswalk at any intersection. 
(Code 1973, §§ 16-3-13, 16-10-2; Code 1994, §§ 38-117, 38-312(d)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-4. 
Sec. 36-540. - When pedestrian to yield right-of-way. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway, street or highway in the city at any point other than within a marked crosswalk, or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon such roadway. 
(b)  The provision of subsection (a) of this section has no application under the conditions stated in section 36-541 when pedestrians are prohibited from crossing at certain designated places. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-5; Code 1994, § 38-315) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-5. 
Sec. 36-541. - Prohibited crossing. 
(a)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway, street or highway in the city, other than in a crosswalk, in any business district. 
(c)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic control devices, and when authorized to cross diagonally, pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-6; Code 1994, § 38-316) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions (as to subsection (a)), G.L. 1956, § 31-18-7. 
Sec. 36-542. - Pedestrians to use right half of crosswalk. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of the crosswalk. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-3; Code 1994, § 38-313) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-9. 
Sec. 36-543. - Crossing street at right angles. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway, street or highway of the city at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb, or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in a marked crosswalk. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-4; Code 1994, § 38-314) 
Sec. 36-544. - Pedestrians walking along roadways. 
    Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to walk along and upon any adjacent roadway, street or highway in the city. Where sidewalks are provided it shall be lawful for a person to run or jog along and upon an adjacent roadway, and if the person shall begin to walk he shall walk upon an available sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-7; Code 1994, § 38-317(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-10. 
Sec. 36-545. - Walking, jogging, or running on left. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are not provided any person walking, jogging, or running along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk, jog or run only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. Under no circumstances shall anyone walk, run, or jog on any interstate. 
(b)  Any person jogging or running during the time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, shall, in addition, wear reflective material which is visible by low beam headlamps from a distance of at least 500 feet. In no event, shall the failure to wear reflective clothing be considered as contributing negligence, nor shall the failure to wear reflective clothing be admissible as evidence in the trial of any civil action. 
(c)  If the person has been charged with failure to wear reflective material, the person shall be issued a citation. If any person issued a citation presents proof of purchase of reflectorized clothing or the minimum amount of reflectorized material to the issuing police department within ten days, the city shall void the violation. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-8; Code 1994, §§ 31-317(b), 38-318) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-10. 
Sec. 36-546. - Soliciting rides or business. 
    No person shall stand, walk or linger in a roadway, street or highway in the city for the purpose of soliciting a ride, or business of any type, from the occupant or driver of a vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 16-10-9; Code 1994, § 38-319; Ord. of 12-10-1990, § 1) 
State Law reference- Hitchhiking in road, G.L. 1956, § 31-18-12. 
Secs. 36-547-36-570. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - VEHICLE CONDITION AND EQUIPMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-571. - Overloading of vehicles. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle when it is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat such number of persons, exceeding three, as to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-16; Code 1994, § 38-96) 
Sec. 36-572. - Obstructions to driver's view. 
    Except as otherwise authorized by law, no person shall drive any motor vehicle or conveyance with any sign, poster, or other nontransparent material, dirt, snow or ice upon the front windshield, side wings, or side or rear windows of such vehicle, which obstructs the driver's view of the highway or intersecting highway. No person shall drive any motor vehicle or conveyance with any significant amounts of snow, ice or sleet upon such vehicle; the term "significant" shall be construed as meaning any amount of accumulation which might reasonably be expected, when blowing off the vehicle when driving, to obscure the vision of the operator of another vehicle; provided, however, that the natural accumulation of snow while driving during adverse weather conditions shall not constitute a violation of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-18; Code 1994, § 38-97) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-23-16. 
Sec. 36-573. - Prevention of excessive fumes and/or smoke. 
    The engine and power mechanism of every motor vehicle or conveyance shall be so equipped and adjusted as to prevent the escape of excessive fumes and/or smoke. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9-19; Code 1994, § 38-98) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, § 31-23-14. 
Sec. 36-574. - Mufflers. 
    Every motor vehicle or conveyance shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke. No person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass, or similar device upon a motor vehicle or conveyance on a highway. Any exhaust system shall be deemed defective if any changes, modifications, alterations, deletions, or adjustments have been made which would thereby cause any exhaust system to generate a higher or louder sound level than would be generated by the exhaust system customarily installed by the manufacturer as original equipment.
